Frances White see www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/21513999655/

There may be two people with the same name that are dancers in vaudeville:
William Rock (1875 - June 27, 1922) 

WILLIAM ROCK OPERATED ON. A Portion of Stomach Removed From Dancer, Recently Married. William Rock, for many years well known as a dancer and comedian in vaudeville and musical ...
New York Times on July 15, 1921.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton] This is certainly the same person. According to 'The Encyclopedia of Vaudeville' by Anthony Slide, page 424, William Rock, whose stagepartner was Frances White, lived from 1875 until 1922. This and the article in the NYT from 1921 (query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9507E0DC173EEE...) prove that the information in travsd.wordpress.com/2013/05/14/stars-of-vaudeville-691-r... is apparently mistaken. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_vaudeville_performers:_L%E2... has 1875 - June 27, 1922 as well.

I added what I could find to Wikipedia: simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Rock His death certificate clears up most of the misinformation about him. He was born on August 5, 1872 in Indiana and was buried in Bowling Green, Kentucky. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._and_Mrs._Sidney_Drew "Mr. & Mrs. Sidney Drew were an American comedy team on stage and screen. The team initially consisted of Sidney Drew (August 28, 1863 – April 9, 1919) and his first wife Gladys Rankin (October 8, 1870 – January 9, 1914). After Gladys died in 1914, Sidney Drew married Lucile McVey (1890–1925), and the two performed as Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Drew." So this is Lucile McVey.

"In the 1850s, U.S. Army Major Albert J. Myer, a surgeon by training, developed a system using left or right movements of a flag (or torch or lantern at night). Myer's system used a single flag, waved back and forth in a binary code conceptually similar to the Morse code of dots and dashes. This is sometimes called the wig-wag method of signaling, or "wig-wagging". " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_signals#Wig-wag_flags

Inventor of the photo booth! " His “Photomaton” debuted in September, 1925 at 1659 Broadway, between 51st and 52nd Streets in Manhattan, and charged 25¢ for a strip of eight photos, which were developed in eight minutes. “[A]s many as 7,500 people a day . . . would line up to have their photos taken,” writes Näkki Goranin in The Telegraph, and “the place came to be known as ‘Broadway’s greatest quarter-snatcher.’ The New York governor and a senator were among those waiting for the fun of the automatic photo strip. A white-gloved attendant would guide people to the booth and, once inside, direct them to ‘look to the right, look to the left, look at the camera.'” In 1927, Josepho sold the patent to his invention to a group led by Henry Morgenthau for $1 million." jewishcurrents.org/march-31-anatol-josephos-photo-booth-2... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anatol_Josepho
Date on negative is 3-29-27

"Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell (1891-1945) was a pilot and an advocate for aviation safety. He graduated from West Point in 1912 and then spent two years as an infantryman in Alaska before transferring to the Signal Corps, where he joined the 1st Aero Squadron, serving under Gen. John J. Pershing in Mexico. On one of his flying missions in Mexico, Gorrell ran out of gas and was stranded in the desert for several days before being rescued. Upon returning to his unit, he began to criticize the poor equipment US pilots were forced to use, both in terms of actual aircraft components and the signals and communication equipment used on land. In 1917 he was promoted to Captain, and in World War I he became the Chief Engineering Officer for the Air Service, and eventually the Chief of Staff for the Air Service, with the rank of Colonel." [NATIONAL AIR AND SPACE ARCHIVES Edgar S. Gorrell Collection ] airandspace.si.edu/research/arch/findaids/pdf/edgar_s_gor...
MAJOR GENERAL BENJAMIN DELAHAUF FOULOIS, 1879-1967 Official Air Force bio: www.af.mil/AboutUs/Biographies/Display/tabid/225/Article/... see also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_Foulois

Virginius E. Clark (1886-1948) www.earlyaviators.com/eclark.htm From the Air Service Journal, August 30, 1917: "Captain VE Clark Capt Virginias E Clark of the Section Signal Corps has been one the most active officers of the army in construction and design of airplanes for the government. For several years after taking a course in aeronautics at the Institute of Technology he specialized in airplane design and until recently had charge of that work. He is abroad on a special mission for the Aviation Section. Captain Clark was recently a member of the Joint Army and Navy Board of Design and Specifications where he passed on similar matters. He was born in Pennsylvania on February 27, 1886 and was graduated from United States Naval Academy in 1907, but was appointed to the Army from civil live in October 1909. At this time he was resident of the State of Pennsylvania, becoming a second lieutenant in the Artillery service. In May 1912 he was promoted to be a first lieutenant. He transferred to the Aviation Section of the Signal Corps in 1914 and was given the rank of captain He is also rated as a military aviator." books.google.com/books?id=scNLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA247&l...
books.google.com/books?id=9y8cBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA25&lp... has more about the board, giving it the name, "Army and Navy Joint Technical Board on Aircraft." Military bios for Towers and Foulois.

Irwin & Leighton, which built the camp (now Fort Dix), is still in business. This from their website: "THE UNITED STATES ARMY CANTONMENT AT CAMP DIX The Camp Dix project, although one of Irwin & Leighton’s earliest, stands even today as one of its most meaningful because of the signifi cance and importance of the project to the World War I effort, and the speed in which it was built. Irwin & Leighton was chosen to build the Cantonment at Camp Dix when the site’s installment began in 1917. The initial project was required to be completed under a very aggressive time schedule to meet the impending demands of World War I. To do this, Irwin & Leighton directly employed and/or coordinated the efforts of hundreds of workers who, in accordance with the custom of the day, arrived at work in shirt and tie, changed into work clothes and changed again to go home. Irwin & Leighton established an onsite Employment Offi ce where seventeen clerks screened applicants who arrived by train and motor car. A fl eet of autos was required to make the weekly commutes to the Philadelphia National Bank for the workers’ payroll. The project started in July of 1917, in farm fi elds. The scope involved ten sections of multiple barracks and support buildings as well as extensive infrastructure work. In less than sixty days, the entire project was substantially complete. In that time, Irwin & Leighton used forty million board feet of lumber, which was brought to the site by rail and erected in production fashion. When the company hit stride, it was completing one barrack per day. Irwin & Leighton’s onsite superintendent was E. M. Campbell. The company further organized the project with “Heads of Departments” for survey, concrete, carpentry, sheet metal, plumbing, electrical, road construction, water and sewers, a pumping station, etc. The 31,000 acre complex is located inside the Pineland National Reserve in Central New Jersey, and was named for Major General John Adams Dix, a veteran of the War of 1812 and the Civil War. Used as a staging ground and training area for units during World War I, it was made a permanent Army post in 1939 and was renamed as Fort Dix." www.irwinleighton.com/images/IL100Years C2.pdf
Now Ft. Dix, N.J., see

This photo exists on the French government archive site Centenaire.org in two places, but with a caption that doesn't exactly describe what is shown in the photo. It seems to be part of a photo series depicting an event off the coast of France on June 19, 1917: One place is a catalog document, describing photo resources held regarding the Vendée Department in Western France, which includes photos relating to an event on June 19, 1917, at Ile d'Yeu off the Vendée coast, in which the Norwegian foreign Minister, probably Fritz Wedel Jarlsberg, no.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fritz_Wedel_Jarlsberg delivered 200,000 francs to the survivors of rescuers who died trying to save those aboard a Norwegian ship torpedoed by a German U-Boat earlier in 1917. "Référence : SPA 83 Z 3336 L'Île-d'Yeu, Vendée. Le ministre des Affaires étrangères de la Norvège, M. Wedel Jarlsberg remet aux marins vendéens sauveteurs du bateau norvégien L'Imer, une somme de 200 000 francs souscrite par ses compatriotes. L'opérateur photographie le ministre et le préfet de Vendée à bord d'une chaloupe, puis d'un bateau. 19 juin 1917. Photographe : Lucien Le Saint/© ECPAD" Per Google Translate: L'Île-d'Yeu, Vendée. The Foreign Minister of Norway, Mr. Wedel Jarlsberg calls to marine rescuers Vendée Imer The Norwegian boat, a sum of 200,000 francs taken out by his countrymen. The operator photographs the Minister and the Prefect of Vendée aboard a boat and a boat. June 19, 1917. Elsewhere in the document: "Le second document présente la visite à L'Île-d'Yeu du ministre des Affaires étrangères de la Norvège venant remettre des titres de rente aux marins survivants et aux veuves des marins morts lors du sauvetage d'un navire norvégien torpillé par un sous-marin allemand." The second document presents the visit to L'Île-d'Yeu the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Norway coming back titles annuity for survivors and widows of sailors sailors died in the rescue of a Norwegian ship torpedoed by a sub German sailor. elsewhere: À L'Île-d'Yeu, le 19 juin 1917, le ministre des Affaires étrangères de la Norvège, M. Wedel Jarlsberg,e par un sousmarin allemand. Les médaillés sont réunis autour du ministre norvégien des Affaires étrangères qui, à la fin de la cérémonie, rejoint une vedette rapide accompagné par le préfet Tardy. Armée d'un canon de 75mm, la vedette rapide quitte, sous les yeux de la foule massée sur le quai, le port de L'Île-d'Yeu où de nombreux bateaux de pêche sont amarrés. Elle évolue en mer puis passe entre les jetées du port des Sables-d'Olonne (Tour d'Arundel) avant d'accoster. At L'Île-d'Yeu, June 19, 1917, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Norway, Mr. Wedel Jarlsberg, just handed annuity titles sailors survivors and widows of the dead sailors in the rescue of a Norwegian ship torpedoed January 20, 1917 by a German submarine. The medalists gathered around the Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs, at the end of the ceremony, joined a speedboat accompanied by the prefect Tardy. Armed with a 75mm gun, the speedboat left, in front of the crowd on the wharf, the port of L'Île-d'Yeu where many fishing boats are moored. It evolves at sea and then passes between the piers of the port of Sables d'Olonne (Tour d'Arundel) before docking. centenaire.org/sites/default/files/references-files/85-ve... The other place the photo is found is in the 16th row, 2nd column of a page of photos from the archive. centenaire.org/fr/tresors-darchives/fonds-publics/autres-...

From oridnepr.pp.ua/video.php?v=0WeN-wc9HEI&t=Soprano%20El... 'Elizabeth Wheeler (pseudonym: Jane Kenyon) Jim Walsh of Hobbies Magazine in 1961 described Elizabeth Wheeler and William Wheeler as "the most successful husband and wife duet pair in the history of the phonograph." She was born Bess Nicholson in Kokomo, Indiana, in 1875; he was born in Shawano, Wisconsin in 1879. They married in 1904, and performed widely, doing standard ballads, light opera, and hymns. Mr. Wheeler made some solo recordings for Leeds & Caitlin, Edison and others, and then the two began their duet recordings in 1910, for Victor. "Beautiful Isle of Somewhere" was an early hit, though it did not reach the 1917 Victor catalog, where there were 17 other titles by the pair. Their final Victor recording was the most popular one, "What a Friend We have in Jesus." Mrs. Wheeler made many solo Victors beginning in 1909; she sang ballads and children's songs, and also "Elizabeth's Prayer" from Tannhauser. William Wheeler did some solo work for Pathe. They did not record after the acoustic period, and "What a Friend" was the only one of their titles to reach the 1927 Victor catalog. Elizabeth Wheeler died in 1971; William Wheeler died in 1967. (From "The Encyclopedia of Recorded Sound in the United States" / edited by Guy A. Marco / Garland Publishing, Inc. - 1993) '

I think they are all synonyms: Monmouth Park Racetrack, Long Branch Racetrack, Hollywood Park Racetrack. The facility changed names with each new owner. The facility looks the same and it still has a big "M' for Monmouth Park in the photo. Sometimes it is listed as in Long Branch, New Jersey and other Times in Oceanport, New Jersey. The borders changed as Long Branch incorporated smaller townships and others were carved out of it. Thoroughbred racing and gambling ended in 1894 and restarted in 1946. I believe in the interim it was used for polo and the Monmouth County Horse Show.

The Saddle and Show Horse Chronicle, Volume 7, 1917-1918 shows that Miss Wanamaker was an extremely successful horsewoman. Page 54 indicates that at the Long Branch Horse Show (July 25-28, 1917), she had fourteen wins in fifteen showings. See books.google.com/books?id=lE85AQAAMAAJ and search for "Long Branch".
There's a Bain shot of her at Long Branch that came up 4 years ago:

The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, August 19, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 59 printed another photo of her in a coach with the text: "Isabel Wanamaker has come to the front in recent years as the owner of one of the finest stables of blooded and show horses in the United States. She was an exhibitor at the Long Branch Horse Show and a winner In several classes." The caption below the photo is 'Isabelle Wanamaker'. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-08-19/ed-1/se... In other sources she appears as Isabelle (or sometimes Isabel) Wanamaker of Philadelphia (e.g. in the Evening public ledger., October 06, 1920, NIGHT EXTRA, Image 32, third row, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1920-10-06/ed-....)

"If a strict comparison was made It Would disclose the fact that Miss Isabella Wanamaker of Merion, Pa. could very properly claim the seasons championship of the equine show ring, for no other exhibitor made Such a wonderful record as did she with the same number of horses. [...] Miss Wanamaker is easily among the most popular of all our exhibitors. [...]_ Her father William H Wanamaker Jr is invariably an interested spectator when she is in the ring and their simple unaffected democratic cordial friendly ways make them among the most sought after of all the addicts of the show ring. 8 publish here the complete list Of MISS Nanamakcr's Seasons winnings (from an account in Show Horse Chronicle in late 1917 of Isabella Wanamaker's season.) books.google.com/books?id=lE85AQAAMAAJ&dq=lsabelle%20...

Saddle and Horse Show magazine indicates Master Luther Tucker of West End, N.J. competed (unsuccessfully) in that category with the pony Patsy. books.google.com/books?id=lE85AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA156&l...
The track in Long Branch where the show took place was known as Hollywood Park. books.google.com/books?id=lE85AQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA156&...

Fridtjof Nansen (/ˈfrɪd.tjɒf ˈnænsən/ frid-choff nan-sən; 10 October 1861 – 13 May 1930) was a Norwegian explorer, scientist, diplomat, humanitarian and Nobel Peace Prize laureate. In his youth a champion skier and ice skater, he led the team that made the first crossing of the Greenland interior in 1888, cross-country skiing on the island, and won international fame after reaching a record northern latitude of 86°14′ during his North Pole expedition of 1893–96. Although he retired from exploration after his return to Norway, his techniques of polar travel and his innovations in equipment and clothing influenced a generation of subsequent Arctic and Antarctic expeditions. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fridtjof_Nansen

In 1917, he was in the United States as head of a Norwegian commission, s. article with photo in The Sunday Oregonian, August 19, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 69. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-08-19/ed-1/se...

From wikipedia: "As the war progressed, the loss of Norway's overseas trade led to acute shortages of food in the country, which became critical in April 1917 when the United States entered the war and placed extra restrictions on international trade. Nansen was dispatched to Washington by the Norwegian government; after months of discussion he secured food and other supplies in return for the introduction of a rationing system. When his government hesitated over the deal, he signed the agreement on his own initiative." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fridtjof_Nansen S. also www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/20698198784/
Thanks to both of you for this research. We'll add some of the information to the record the next time we update.
Louis Raemakers (1869-1956), was a Belgian-American artist
See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/21294643316/

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Raemaekers "Immediately after the Germans invaded Belgium, Louis Raemaekers became one of their fiercest critics. His message was clear: the Netherlands had to take sides for the Allies and abandon its neutral stance. His graphic cartoons depicted the rule of the German military in Belgium, portrayed the Germans as barbarians and Kaiser Wilhelm II as an ally of Satan." He visited the U.S. in 1917. "His tour was a triumph. Raemaekers gave lectures and interviews, drew caricatures for the movie cameras, was a popular guest at society functions, and met President Woodrow Wilson and former President Theodore Roosevelt. Soon after his arrival he signed – to everyone's surprise – a contract with the International News Service, the syndicate of William Randolph Hearst. The Hearst newspapers were viewed as pro-German and had been cut off from all Allied news sources. But Raemaekers' own theory: 'this is the most important target group because the readers are poisoned daily by tendentious articles' proofed [sic] successful. Statistics show that by October 1917, more than two thousand American newspapers had published Raemaekers’ cartoons in hundreds of million copies. The popularisation of his work is regarded as the largest propaganda effort of the First World War."
Thank you swanq for this great background information about the artist.  We'll add some of the information to the record the next time we update.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/ryan_loc] : I see that LoC has digitized some of Raemaekers' cartoons in miscellaneous Prints and Photographs collections, but most are not available offsite. Exceptions include www.loc.gov/item/2003677570/ and www.loc.gov/resource/cph.3b52913/ A book of his cartoons from LoC's collections has been digitized and can be seen at archive.org/details/raemaekerscartoo01raem

Louis Raemakers (1869-1956), was a Belgian-American artist

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_Raemaekers The Sunday Oregonian, August 19, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 69 printed this photo with the caption: "Louis Raemakers, the famous Dutch cartoonist, was almost unknown on this side of the water when the war began. But his anti-Germar cartoons gained for him a world-wide reputation. He was acclaimed In America with such a warmth that he decided to come over and see us, and he is in New York for a brief stay." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-08-19/ed-1/se...

Here's a link to an original anti-war cartoon drawing by Raemaekers at the Library of Congress, www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3b52913/. Title: "I say, do suggest something new. This is becoming too boring." Subject: An elegantly dressed devil, symbol of war, with a cigarette in hand, sits toward the rear of a yawning warrior, Ares, the god of battles, who has placed his bloody sword on the floor. Published in: Raemaekers' Cartoons; with Accompanying Notes by Well-Known English Writers / by Louis Raemaekers. Garden City, N.Y.: Doubleday, Page & Co., 1916

books.google.com/books?id=_9spAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA215&l... has a picture that shows Taylor and Simons at the Mineola aviation station.

Judging from en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Field_%28Airfield%29 the photo must have been taken between May 3, 1917 when Ralph L. Taylor of Stamford, CT was commissioned as Captain and August 2, 1917, when he was killed in an accident. A military airfield in Alabama was named Taylor Field after him.
books.google.com/books?id=eIkoAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA247&l... shows a Henry H. Simons as a captain in November 1918.

Aerial Age Weekly, April 12, 1915 books.google.com/books?id=UWNVAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA85&lp... mentions Lieutenant H.G. Smith as involved in the organization of a Canadian branch of the Royal Flying Corps. So the lefthand man may be a Canadian aviator.

Flying, Volume 7, p 341, May 1918, books.google.com/books?id=q5FMAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA341&l... has a picture that includes H.G. Smith. The captain describes him as an instructor, but as in the Bain caption, he is not given a military rank, perhaps because he was not a citizen and was employed in the U.S. as a civilian. The man in the middle of the photo in Flying is compatible with the lefthand man here.

Aerial Age Weekly, Oct 1, 1917 books.google.com/books?id=g1gfAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA107&l... reports that First Lieut. B.S. Robertson, Jr. was assigned to Signal Corps Aviation School, Chanute Field, Mount Clemens, Michigan.
Benjamin S. Robertson, Jr. was still a 1st Lieutenant as of November, 1918. books.google.com/books?id=GUNTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA318&d...

The Russian ambassador to Japan in 1917 was Vasily Nikolaevich Krupensky (1868-1945) He was ambassador from 1916-1921. Krupensky is the modern transliteration and is more accurate to the original Russian Крупенский than Kurupensky, used by Bain. ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%B...
see also

The website of THE EMBASSY OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION TO JAPAN gives his name as Krupensky Vasily Nikolaevich as well, but according to that he was ambassador in 1916 and 1917 only, s. www.russia-emb.jp/english/embassy/history/index.html

He was there until 1921.  I think the difference may have something to do with the 1917 revolution and subsequent civil war and which Russian government Krupensky represented.  According the embassy site, there was no ambassador between 1918 and 1925.

This group of 14 photos is related to two Bain photos posted earlier of men testing the L.W.F. Model V Tractor training aircraft, as identified by Flickr user TVL1970 in comments to and "The Lowe Willard & Fowler (L.W.F.) Engineering Company, located at College Point, New York City, was organized in 1915 for the manufacture of all types of heavier-than-air machines. L.W.F. produced the first all-American aircraft to be used during World War I. In 1917, the first Liberty motor to fly was installed in the L.W.F. Model G, and several of the L.W.F. aircraft held performance records for speed and endurance. The company also completed Government contracts for producing Martin Bombers, Douglas DT-2s, and Naval Observation Planes, before the company dissolved in 1924." siris-archives.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?uri=full=3100001~!2...

Similar to this photo at the Imperial War Museum site: "THE FRENCH ARMY IN SALONIKA DURING THE FIRST WORLD WAR part of "MINISTRY OF INFORMATION FIRST WORLD WAR OFFICIAL COLLECTION" (photographs) Made by: Varges, Ariel 1917-11-29 French 75mm field gun mounted for use as an anti-aircraft weapon." www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/205221838 THE FRENCH ARMY IN SALONIKA DURING THE FIRST WORLD WAR© IWM (HU 91353)

B-59's link identifies the man at right as General Dubail, Military Governor of Paris. "Auguste Yvon Edmond Dubail (15 April 1851 - 7 January 1934) was a French Army general. He commanded the First Army and Army Group East during World War I. [...] When the German offensive began at Verdun, Joffre partly blamed Dubail, who was fired in March 1916, publicly humiliated. He claimed to have been made a scapegoat for Joffre’s lack of foresight, although he had himself public played down the likelihood of a German attack at Verdun.[citation needed] Dubail was hired again and became military governor of Paris, a position he kept until the spring 1918, when he retired from public life. Dubail died in 1934, aged 82." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auguste_Dubail

I think the person indentified as Dubail by the Ogden standard is not the same person. The uniform seems different. The man on the right in the Bain photo could be Dubail IMO (in this case the caption of the Ogden Standard was mistaken), or it's possibly Ferdinand Foch (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Foch). PS: I came to the conclusion that the officer identified as Dubail by the Ogden standard is likely Foch.

You are probably right and this is a subject for further research. This 4th of July event in Paris in 1917 was copiously documented in photos and films, so hopefully some clearer photos than the one in the Ogden Standard will give an answer.

The sun., July 22, 1917, Section 4 Pictorial Magazine, Image 38 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1917-07-22/ed-... has photos of Gen. Pershing at the tomb of Lafayette and of Pershing with Gen. Dubail. The same photo, taken likely on July 4, 1917, in better qualitiy and with Gen. Foch on the left, ran in The Daily Ardmoreite., December 01, 1918, Image 11 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042303/1918-12-01/ed-.... Both French generals are wearing the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honour. Foch has a leather strap on his uniform, contrary to Dubail. I think therefore that the French general on the photo in The Ogden standard chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1917-07-25/ed-... is indeed Foch. The stripes on the pants and the boots suggest that the French general on the Bain photo is Dubail.

Sir Eric Campbell-Geddes GCB, GBE, PC (26 September 1875 – 22 June 1937) was a British businessman and Conservative politician. With a background in railways, he served as head of Military Transportation on the Western Front, with the rank of Major-General. He then served as First Lord of the Admiralty (with the rank of Vice-Admiral, despite its being a political position) between 1917 and 1919. He then served as the first Minister of Transport between 1919 and 1921, in which position he was responsible for the deep public spending cuts known as the "Geddes Axe". en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eric_Campbell_Geddes

They married on 9 November 1922 and this image was taken in March of 1931 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hermine_Reuss_of_Greiz en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Henriette_of_Sch%C3%B6naic... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_102-11383,_D...

Richard Norton: 
Thank you for your information and for the link to the similar image at the Bundesarchiv.  I agree that the depicted people are Wilhelm II, his second wife Hermine Reuss of Greiz, and Hermine’s daughter Princess Henriette.

However, I think the 1931 date attributed to the photograph is incorrect. The date of 5/10/27 is written on the Bain negative.  Princess Henriette was born in 1918. If the image was taken in 1931, she would have been about 13 years old. She looks younger to me, closer to the age she would have been in 1927 or earlier, about 9 years old. The Bundesarchiv image bears this note:  “For documentary purposes the German Federal Archive often retained the original image captions, which may be erroneous, biased, obsolete or politically extreme.”   It appears that probably the original image caption was in error in this case.  

We will add more information to the description when we update.

"In the 1850s, U.S. Army Major Albert J. Myer, a surgeon by training, developed a system using left or right movements of a flag (or torch or lantern at night). Myer's system used a single flag, waved back and forth in a binary code conceptually similar to the Morse code of dots and dashes. This is sometimes called the wig-wag method of signaling, or "wig-wagging". " en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_signals#Wig-wag_flags

Art Siegel and B-59: Thank you for the details. Looks like another photo of the Peekskill training camp for boys.  We will add more information to the description.

Despite the enscription, this isn't "wig-wag" - wig-wag was a single-flag signaling method, originally used for Myer Code, but after 1912, used for Morse code.

Since two flags are evident, this would be semaphore signaling, as shown in this 1914 signal training device:
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/aemays/7121567929]

The single-flag Wig-Wag signal method, conveniently, is depicted on the other side of the 1914 signal training device, as here:
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/aemays/6975490928]
Thanks again [https://www.flickr.com/photos/signalmirror], I'll ask someone to fix the catalog record.

Per The Tennessean (Newspaper)
By Frank Daniels III fdanielsiii@tennessean.com

We often cite the establishment, in 1958, of the Department of Defense's Advanced Research Projects Agency, and its creation of the first packet-switched network, ARPAnet, as the beginning of the Internet.

But the American military's work in creating the Internet can be dated to 1910, when Army officer George Owen Squier (pronounced like "square") invented a way to let a telephone line carry multiple signals at one time. His discovery, multiplexing, paved the way for the development of telephone and data networks; as did his later invention of sending music over electric wires.

First Ph.D. in the Army

Squier was born in Dryden, Mich., on March 21, 1865, and graduated from West Point military academy when he was 22. He was a rare intellect. He was accepted to Johns Hopkins University, and, in 1893, became the Army's first person to receive a doctorate.

He spent his career inventing and forging new structures in the U.S. Army.

His first invention, in 1896, with Albert Cushing Crehore, was a camera that measured the speed of warheads as they left the barrel of a cannon.

Pioneer of aeronautics

Squier was assigned to the U.S. Signal Corps after the Spanish-American War, where he was responsible for creating the Aeronautical Division. He was the first Army officer to fly on an airplane, and, in 1909, was part of the team that bought the Army's first airplanes from the Wright brothers.

The aeronautics division was responsible for developing the communications and navigation equipment and procedures for military aircraft.

In 1910, while searching for ways to increase the number of calls Signal Corps could handle on its telephone network, Squier developed a way to multiplex calls, similar to how multiple signals could be bundled together on the telegraph network, called carrier frequency.

He was promoted to major general and chief signals officer for the Army during World War I, responsible for all communications and aviation during the war.

In 1919, he was elected to the National Academy of Science for his work in telephony, radio and aviation.

'Grandfather of the Internet'

Building on his multiplexing work, in 1922, Squier developed a system to "pipe" music using electric wires. He was granted a number of patents covering the delivery of music and other information over wires. His ideas are foundational to the concept of the Internet.

His Wired Radio Inc. became popular under the brand Muzak.

Squier retired from the Army in 1924, and died in Washington on March 24, 1934.

The troop ship USS General G.O. Squier was named in his honor in 1943.

Reach Frank Daniels III at 615-881-7039, and on Twitter: @fdanielsiii.

The Sunday Oregonian, August 12, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 67 printed a similar photo of McQuade with the caption: "JUDGE F. X. M'QUADE, of New York, started a charity on the line of those maintained by "Big Tim" Sullivan for many years before his death. "Big Tim" was a steady friend of the "down-and-outer" on the Bowery. Once a year he had a distribution of shoes to these homeless men. Always he was ready to help them to a meal. He said that the quickest way to start a man on the up road was to fill his belly. Judge McQuade has interested some philanthropic men in the starting of a restaurant for homeless men on the Bowery. It will open at midnight every night and any man who wants a meal can go in and get one free. It is estimated that 2000 meals a night will be given away and that their cost will be 15 cents each. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-08-12/ed-1/se...

Alexander T. Ovenshine (1873-1963): "Samuel Ovenshine's son, Alexander, was also a career military officer who rose to the rank of general. He is not buried in Arlington, however, but in San Antonio, Texas. Alexander Thompson Ovenshine of Kansas Appointed Private, Corporal, and Sergeant, Company C, 21st United States Infantry, 1 May 1894 to 28 February 1897 Second Lieutenant, 17th United States Infantry, 16 February 1897 First Lieutenant, 23rd United States Infantry. 6 February 1899 Captain, 7th United States Infantry, 14 October 1901 Fort Sam Houston Texas, National Cemetery: Alexander Thompson Ovenshine Born 25 June 1873 Died 6 March 1963 Brigadier General Plot: E 56 Buried 8 March 1963" www.arlingtoncemetery.net/sovenshine.htm Details of his WWI service which earned him the Distinguished Service Medal: valor.militarytimes.com/recipient.php?recipientid=18003

The next photo in your set is 4265-2 says taken at Fort Slocum. I'm fairly certain that the building shown here was the Bachelors Officers' Quarters at Fort Slocum, New York. These were standardized plans from the earliest part of the 20th century, but the key here is he Bachelor Officer's Quarters with mess hall and porch that you see to the left. The Army extensively used standardized plans for its buildings but not for its posts.

F.G. Mauldin, probably Frank G. Mauldin, here seen at Camp Cody: demingnewmexico.genealogyvillage.com/CampCody/cc01.htm In December, 1916, he was given command of Fort Slocum: " Lieut Col Frank G Mauldin is detailed for general recruiting service and will proceed to Fort Slocum and assume command of that post and of the recruit depot thereat ..." books.google.com/books?id=-lM-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA716&l...

Thanks Art and Adam. I believe this is Col. Frank G. Mauldin. I searched around and I found that there was a Maj. Alexander Thompson Ovenside assigned to Fort Slocum also so that would make it very likely this is Fort Slocum.

from Wikipedia:
" By the onset of World War I it had become one of the busiest recruiting stations in the country, processing 100,000 soldiers per year and serving as the recruit examination station for soldiers from New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and the New England states. Between 1917 and 1919, over 140,000 recruits passed through the post. In fact, Recruit Week in December 1917 brought so many recruits to Fort Slocum that an overflow had to be housed in New Rochelle."
Thank you Richard Norton and Art Siegel. We will add more information on Fort Slocum when we update.

The aircraft featured in this and adjacent photo is the L.W.F. Model V Tractor training aircraft. (Special thanks to the Secret Projects Forum). See: www.flugzeuginfo.net/acdata_php/acdata_lwf_vtractor_en.php www.aerofiles.com/lwf-v.jpg www.theaerodrome.com/forum/showthread.php?t=33640 The aircraft is somewhat unusual for the era and American aircraft construction in that the fuselage is of (then) advanced laminated wood monocoque construction. L.W.F. Company designed and built the aircraft. "L.W.F." came from the last initials of its founders, Edward Lowe, Jr., Charles Willard, and Robert G. Fowler. Both Willard and Fowler were renown aviators of the era. See: earlyaviators.com/efowler1.htm earlyaviators.com/efowler2.htm en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_G._Fowler earlyaviators.com/ewillard.htm [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/20372183405/in/photostream/]

Diagonal striped one in the top right may be the 3rd Infantry Division flag. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3rd_Infantry_Division_(United_States)

The upper left flag is the US Navy jack flag which was flown on all Navy ships. The others, aside from the two in the center are Navy signal flags. The upper center one is rather obvious, but the lower center one is a bit confusing. It appears to be the Prussian coat of arms, although it's backward because the "FR" (for Fridericus Rex) is reversed. Maybe the Navy was using it in training, perhaps on dummy target ships.
Thanks for locating this photo in a newspaper B-59. We'll be sure to identify this as the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Since I can't add notes to the image.

There is a steam engine behind the worker, you can see its flywheel.  The machines are belt driven from shafts turned by the steam engine.  There are about 4 pieces of wood clamped for drilling simultaneously.  The pieces drilled previously have been posed on the bench to illustrate what she is doing.  There appears to be a tally chalked on the side of the machine.
plus she's standing in an enormous pile of drillings... open belts, flying splinters, no interfering shields of any kind.. no dangers here OSHA!  move along...

Likely Helene Ethel Cassidy (1882 - 1944), wife of Warren Charles Fairbanks and daughter in law of Charles Warren Fairbanks, Vice President of the United States from 1905 to 1909. www.ancestry.com/genealogy/records/helene-ethel-cassidy_2... www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7444282 Another photo of her is in The Indianapolis journal., September 22, 1903, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015679/1903-09-22/ed-...

Thanks B-59 for figuring out this woman's name. I searched around for other photos to confirm it and I discovered that a magazine called "The Spur" used this photo, full page, in it's October 1, 1917 issues (p. 20). I does identify her as Ethel Cassidy and says that since her father-in-law, former Vice President Charles Fairbanks, is a widower, she serves as his hostess. It also mentions she has been interested in Red Cross during the past year.

This photo probably shows the 5th Marines move by rail from the Philadelphia Navy Yard to the port of New York between June 8th and 12th 1917.  The 5th Marines (an infantry regiment) were activated at the Philadelphia Navy Yard on June 7th, 1917.  The regiment sailed to France in two vessels (USS Henderson and USS Hancock)  on June 14th and 17th, as part of the first shipment of American troops to the war zone.  The USS Henderson sailed from the port of New York.  Rail transport from Philadelphia to New York would probably have been via the Pennsylvania Railroad, the owner of the coach shown in the photo.

William George Haan (October 4, 1863 - October 26, 1924) was a general in World War I. He graduated from West Point in 1889, from the Army War College in 1905, and was commissioned in the Artillery. He served in Cuba and the Philippines, and in 1903 went to Panama at the request of Theodore Roosevelt. He was Acting Chief of Staff of the Pacific Division during the Army's relief work following the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_G._Haan

There's a total of five men wearing captured German steel helmets, two men wearing German softcover caps (the Krätzchen worn by enlisted men), and in the center between them one guy with a spiked helmet (Pickelhaube). The stick hand grenades and the machine guns could also be German, but I don't know enough about them to say for sure.

No, this is the State Landau of the Royal Family. See www.britishroyals.info/royal-wedding-carriages-revealed/ My guess is that although the Illustrated London News shows that the King and Queen came in an open carriage, some other family members came in this coach.

The third photo of the subway porter bears a number on the negative in sequence with the call numbers of the other two, but it has a call number of LOT 10969 (instead of its original Bain number 4248-17), as it was placed in a group of photos called "Women's war work, 1917-1918, mostly in New York City." See www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=LOT%2010969&fi=number&... So it will not come up now in sequence when you search the Bain collection for photos in the 4248 series, which is too bad, as it makes researching the photos in context with the ones nearby in sequence difficult. Perhaps when this LOT was created, its makers took the glass negative out of the Bain collection and physically moved it. Another possibility is that a copy was made for the LOT, but the original negative left in the Bain collection was later lost or destroyed. This happened to other photos in the Bain collection, like this shot of Helen Campbell, originally Bain 4204-12. www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3b01181/ and this subway-related shot, Bain 4377-14; www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2007678625/ Both now cataloged in the LOT referenced above. This certainly accounts for some of the many numbering gaps in the Bain collection.

Searching for "photo by Bain News Service" reveals 156 photos which are in other collections, some of which bear Bain catalog numbers which are not their call numbers. www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=Photo%20by%20Bain%20News%2...

The photo shows a courtesan (oiran) and her child protegee, a kamuro. Please do not mistake them for geisha, or geisha girls. These three professions are different from one another. An oiran was trained in various traditional arts, including but not limited to classical dance, playing musical instruments and calligraphy. In addition, she would also be available for sex. The profession no longer exist and nowadays only actresses wear these costumes.

Geisha do not offer sex. The name of their profession betrays their occupation as a "person of art". They are professional dancers and musicians, just like the oiran, but without the sexual part and in different styles of art. That's not to say there was never sex involved between a geisha and her customer, but it was not a requirement of the profession. 

Lastly, the term "geisha girl" was given after World War II by American GI's stationed in Japan, who were looking for prostitutes whom they called "geisha girls". Even less information than today was available about the geisha back then, and to hear of women providing service to entertain men... they just drew the wrong conclusion. Some women used that misconception to their benefit and as such, the term "geisha girl" and its matching misunderstanding was born.
Did this profession disappear before, or after the Japanese defeat in World War Two?

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/118353874@N05] Prostitution was made illegal in 1958, so that is when the profession of the oiran officially ended. However, they weren't around much at that time anyway, as geisha had (since their appearance in the 18th century) mostly replaced them as a source of entertainment.
The child understudy is particularly disturbing.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/118353874@N05] You might be interested in reading books.google.nl/books?id=4T-kJB8vKvcC&lpg=PA84&ot... for more information about kamuro.

My husband is the grd son of “Jacques Achille Boyriven” nicknamed the aviator in our family.  I can assure you this Bains News photo is not of him. The ID was wrong back then already.  We have many family photos in addition to my husband’s recollection as a kid. The aviator never ever wore a mustache.  He was tall and very skinny.
From a military point of view, he wore 3 “chevron” in his sleeves: a Captain.
The other aviators who went with him to the US to train the first US air corps were all lieutenants with 2 chevrons on their sleeves.
I was personally in touch with descendants of some of the other pilots and the family of Gautier is sure it is their grd father.  They too have photo albums of their ancestor to cross-reference.
This might sound a trivial quest, but it is important for the descendants.

These are the officers of the First Telegraph Battalion, Signal Corps (which later became the 406th Telegraph Battalion(. This battalion was recruited from employees of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania. They trained in Monmouth Park, NJ in June and July, 1917. This information comes from a 1921 illustrated history of the battalion. Maj. Hubbell was the battalion Commander, Lt. Greist was the Adjutant, Capts. Wattles and Hollister commanded companies "D" and "E", respectively. Lts. Suddath and Gauss reported to Capt. Hollister, who left the battalion in late July, 1917 for medical reasons. The battalion left for combat in France in early August. books.google.com/books?id=GjS0AAAAMAAJ&dq=major+james... Further info from Army and Navy Register Signal Corps commissioned reserve officers: Capt. Wm. P. Wattles, Philadelphia (5/19/17) (a Major by the time of the 1921 history) Capt. Roy C. Hollister, Pittsburgh (5/16/17) 1st. Lt. Thomas H. Griest, Philadelphia (5/16/17) (a Major by the time of the 1921 history) Maj. James W. Hubbell, New York (5/12/17 (Lt. Col. at the time of the 1921 history) 1st Lt. Leroy N. Suddath, Scranton (5/12/17) 1st Lt. William F. Gauss, (5/12/17) (a Major by the time of the 1921 history) Army & Navy Register. ... v.61 1917 babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=coo.31924069767063;view=1u...

In 1941, James Hubbell became president of the New York Telephone Company (Bell System) the largest telephone operating company in the U.S. nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn88075693/1941-08-27/ed-1...
Thomas Griest (1884-1947) is buried at Arlington National Cemetary. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=griest...;

Hmmm, somewhat unusual for this photo to be in this group of World War I-era photos from the Bain collection. As the reversed inscription in the lower left corner of the frame denotes, this photo was taken in April 1927. Pictured are the doomed aviators Noel Davis and Stanton Wooster, apparently standing on the wing of the ill-fated Keystone K-47 Pathfinder named "American Legion" (reg. N-X 179). Both Davis and Wooster were preparing to fly the American Legion across the Atlantic for the Orteig Prize (ultimately won by Charles Lindbergh flying the Ryan NYP "Spririt of St. Louis" from Roosevelt Field, Long Island to Paris just weeks later) when this photo was taken. Davis and Wooster would perish in a crash landing of the American Legion on April 26, 1927. Ultimately, the aircraft would be salvaged and rebuilt into an airliner which would fly passengers and mail for West Indian Aerial Services and Pan American Airways (PAA "Pan Am"). See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wooster_and_Davis en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystone_Pathfinder

It's apparent from another photo of this event from the New York Herald, June 10, 1917, that the woman addressing the recruits between the big guns is Margaret M. Crumpacker, Commandant of the Woman's Auxiliary for Naval Recruiting, later called the League for Sailors Comfort and Cheer. fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald... bklyn.newspapers.com/image/55633045/ Margaret Murray Crumpacker was the second wife and widow of Jonathan W. Crumpacker, a member of a prominent Indiana political family who had been a state senator and was a federal appointee to the New Mexico territorial supreme court. She came to New York after his death in 1904 and went to France in December, 1915 to aid with the wounded and see the trenches first hand. She was active in WWI preparedness, then in recruiting after the U.S. entered the war in 1917. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=24441555 www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=24441588 archives.chicagotribune.com/1916/10/01/page/7/article/hom...

Karen, given their construction and shape, those are almost certainly fuel tanks for installation in the Keystone K-47 Pathfinder "American Legion" (reg. N-X179). Field Marshal Herbert Charles Onslow Plumer, 1st Viscount Plumer, GCB GCMG GCVO GBE (13 March 1857 – 16 July 1932) was a senior British Army officer of the First World War. After commanding V Corps at the Second Battle of Ypres in April 1915, he took command of the Second Army in May 1915 and in June 1917 won an overwhelming victory over the German Army at the Battle of Messines, which started with the simultaneous explosion of a series of mines placed by the Royal Engineers' tunnelling companies beneath German lines, which created 19 large craters and was described as the loudest explosion in human history. He later served as Commander-in-Chief of the British Army of the Rhine and then as Governor of Malta before becoming High Commissioner of the British Mandate for Palestine in 1925 and retiring in 1928. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Plumer,_1st_Viscount_Plumer

Charles Linza McNary (June 12, 1874 – February 25, 1944) was a United States Republican politician from Oregon. He served in the Senate from 1917 to 1944, and was Senate Minority Leader from 1933 to 1944. In the Senate, McNary helped to pass legislation that led to the construction of Bonneville Dam on the Columbia River, and worked on agricultural and forestry issues. He also supported many of the New Deal programs at the beginning of the Great Depression. Until Mark O. Hatfield surpassed his mark in 1993, he was Oregon’s longest serving senator. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_L._McNary

New York Community Chorus dinner Arthur Finley Nevin (April 27, 1871 – July 10, 1943) was an American composer, conductor, teacher and musicologist. Along with Charles Wakefield Cadman, Blair Fairchild, Charles Sanford Skilton, and Arthur Farwell, among others, he was one of the leading Indianist composers of the early twentieth century. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Nevin Frances Isabelle (Lockwood) Brundage (1854–1937) was an American illustrator best known for her depictions of attractive and endearing children on postcards, valentines, calendars, and other ephemera published by Raphael Tuck & Sons, Samuel Gabriel Company, and Saalfield Publishing. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frances_Brundage Marian MacDowell (maiden name Marian Griswold Nevins) (November 22, 1857 – August 23, 1956) was a pianist, and in 1907 the founder and developer of the MacDowell Colony, an art colony in Peterborough, New Hampshire, United States. Her leadership of the Colony through two world wars, the Great Depression and other challenges created one of the foremost art institutions in the United States, which cultivated the work of generations. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marian_MacDowell

Not the New York Community Chorus Dinner, I think, but the National Conference on Community Music, May 31-June 1, 1917, Astor Hotel, New York. The men cited by Richard Norton and: Mrs. Howard Mansfield Mrs. Kate Douglas Wiggin Mrs. David Allen Campbell William J. McCoy Arthur Farwell -were all speakers at the National Conference on Community Music. Only Mrs. G.B. Carpenter at this table was not. Their addresses and speeches online at babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3563560;view=2up;seq=... McCoy's speech was titled: "An Illustrated Talk on The Forest Festival (Midsummer High Jinks) of the Bohemian Club of San Francisco, by William J. McCoy, of San Francisco" Mrs. David Allen Campbell was described as "Chairman of the Committee on Community Music of the National Council of Women of the United States." Mrs. George B. Carpenter was described as "Mrs. George B. Carpenter, Leader, Chicago Civic Music Association." Arthur Farwell described as "Arthur Farwell, Director of the New York Music School Settlement. President of the New York Community Chorus."

According to the source cited by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog], Helen C. Mansfield was President of the National Association of Music School Societies. She was Helen Coolidge (born 1860), who married James Chesbro Tuttle in 1881 and Howard Mansfield in 1898 - research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord.php?-action=... - research.frick.org/directoryweb/browserecord.php?-action=...

Mrs. George B. Carpenter was likely Lucy Adeline Boone (born 1851), who married George Benedict Carpenter in 1871. Alice Brady (born Mary Rose Brady, November 2, 1892 – October 28, 1939) was an American actress who began her career in the silent film era and survived the transition into talkies. She worked up until six months before her death from cancer in 1939. Her films include My Man Godfrey (1936), in which she played the flighty mother of Carole Lombard's character, and In Old Chicago (1937) for which she won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_Brady

NYT of May 28, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9400E5D7123AE433A... indicates that a benefit was happening that evening at the Hotel des Artistes for Stage Women’s War Relief. The benefit would feature Ruth Roland, Alice Brady, as well as Roshanara and Ratan Levi. Since photos of these three and several close to them are in the same location, it seems likely that this is the occasion.

She appeared at this event as Huckleberry Finn, see photo in The Sunday Oregonian, June 17, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 66. The caption is: "Pretty Ruth Roland appeared at the entertainment given by the stars of the movie world under Mrs. Stuart Blackton's direction recently garbed as Mark Twain's "Huckleberry Finn". Afterward she appeared on the dancing floor as her own self. More than $2000 was raised for comfort kits by this entertainment." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-06-17/ed-1/se...

This is presumably the ceremony at Columbia University on May 10, 1917 in which Joffre and Viviani, along with Balfour and Lord Cunliffe, were awarded honorary degrees in an outdoor ceremony. Prince Kuni Kuniyoshi (久邇宮邦彦王 Kuni-no-miya Kuniyoshi ō?, 23 June 1873 – 29 June 1929) was a member of the Japanese imperial family and a field marshal in the Imperial Japanese Army during the Meiji and Taishō periods. He was the father of Empress Kōjun (who in turn was the consort of the Emperor Shōwa), and therefore, the maternal grandfather of the present emperor of Japan, Akihito. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Kuni_Kuniyoshi

"Yamanashi" may be an error for "Nashimoto," as no imperial branch family existed with the former name. Prince Nashimoto Morimasa (梨本宮守正王 Nashimoto no miya Morimasa ō?, 9 March 1874 – 2 January 1951) was a member of the Japanese imperial family, field marshal in the Imperial Japanese Army. An uncle-in-law of Emperor Shōwa, an uncle of his consort, Empress Kōjun, and the father-in-law of Crown Prince Euimin of Korea, Prince Nashimoto was the only member of the imperial family arrested for war crimes during the American occupation of Japan following the Second World War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Nashimoto_Morimasa

Assuming this photo was taken around 1917, this man is far too young to be Prince Nashimoto Morimasa (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince_Nashimoto_Morimasa), who was born in 1874 IMO (and I think it was taken in 1917, because Prince Kuni looks like 44 years). A Prince Yamanashi as a member of the Imperial Household is mentioned in military.wikia.com/wiki/Wataru_Kaji as student at the Tokyo Imperial University in 1923. (This text apparently comes from 'Dilemma In Japan' by Andrew Roth, 1945, page 235 archive.org/details/dilemmainjapan017811mbp)

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Believe you may be right about his age, but I still can't find a "Yamanashi" among the imperial branch houses by searching the Japanese web. Adriaan Schade van Westrum (1865 - 1917) This photo ran in the New-York tribune., May 20, 1917, Page 14 (with obituary) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-05-20/ed-... The Sunday Oregonian, June 03, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 75 printed a similar photo with the caption: "The world of literature suffered a loss in the death, recently, of Adrian Schade Van Westrum, one of the most noted literary critics in America. A native of Amsterdam, Mr. Van Westrum came to this country more than 3O years ago. Son of a family widely known in Holland, he had received a broad education and achieved a mastery of many languages. He had studied the literature of many countries; and he arrived in the United Statee thoroughly equipped for one of the most exacting of professions. His first work was done on "Book Chat." Afterward he was connected editorially with "The Critic" and other literary publications, and with the book departments of daily newspapers, becoming five years ago the assistant literary critic of the Tribune. He succeeded about a year later to the control of the literary page, which he conducted in a way to command the respect of the literary as well as the publishing world." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-06-03/ed-1/se...

Alexander Berkman (November 21, 1870 – June 28, 1936) was an anarchist known for his political activism and writing. He was a leading member of the anarchist movement in the early 20th century. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Berkman

In Living My Life, Volume 2, Emma Goldman books.google.com/books?id=WwLCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA615&l... notes that Berkman had a leg injury when he and Goldman were in court on June 27, 1917 to face charges of conspiracy to defeat the selective draft. The date scribbled on the negative is definitely June 1917, but likely the 10th or 20th. See Goldman in next photo: In books.google.com/books?id=WwLCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA599&l... she describes Berkman's accident in mid-May 1917.

Emma Goldman (June 27 [O.S. June 15], 1869 – May 14, 1940) was an anarchist known for her political activism, writing, and speeches. She played a pivotal role in the development of anarchist political philosophy in North America and Europe in the first half of the 20th century. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emma_Goldman
Goldman and Alexander (Sasha) Berkman were in the news in May and June 1917 for their opposition to the "selective draft."

The file description on the LOC website has some names listed as "unknown". I was able to locate the full list of names in the photo. The Imperial War Museum dates the photograph May 1, 1917. This was the end of the first session of the cabinet which met from 20 March to 2 May 1917. Back Row (Left to Right): Capt. Leo S. Amery, M.P. (1873-1955), Admiral Sir John Jellicoe (1859-1935) (First Sea Lord of the Admiralty), Sir Edward Carson (1854-1935) (First Lord of the Admiralty), Edward Stanley, 17th Earl of Derby (1865-1948) (Secretary for War), Major-General Frederick Barton Maurice (1871-1951) (Director of Military Operations, Imperial General Staff), Lieut.-Col Maurice Hankey, 1st Baron Hankey (1877-1963) (Secretary to Committee of Imperial Defence), Mr Henry Lambert (Secretary to the Imperial Conference), and Major Lancelot Storr (1874-1944) (Assistant Secretary). Middle Row: Sir S.P. Sinha (First Native Member of Viceroy's Council, India), The Maharajah of Bikanir Ganga Singh (1880-1943) (representing the Ruling Princes of India), Sir James Meston, 1st Baron Meston (1865-1943) (Lieutenant-Governor of United Provinces of Agra and Oudh), The Rt. Hon. Austen Chamberlain (Secretary for India), The Rt. Hon. Lord Robert Cecil, 1st Viscount Cecil of Chelwood (1864-1958) (Minister of Blockade), The Rt. Hon. Walter H. Long, 1st Viscount Long (1854-1924) (Colonial Secretary), The Rt. Hon. Sir Joseph Ward (1856-1930) (Finance Minister, New Zealand), The Hon. Sir George Halsey Perley (1857-1938) (Minister of Canadian Overseas Forces), The Hon. Robert Rogers (1864-1936) (Canadian Minister of Public Works), and The Hon. John Douglas Hazen (1860-1937) (Canadian Minister of Marine). Front Row: The Rt. Hon. Arthur Henderson (Minister without portfolio) (1863-1935), The Rt. Hon Lord Alfred Milner, 1st Viscount Milner, (Minister without portfolio) (1854-1925), Lord Curzon (Lord President of the Council), The Rt. Hon. Bonar Law (Chancellor of the Exchequer), The Rt. Hon. D. Lloyd George (Premier), The Rt Hon. Sir Robert Borden (Premier of Canada), The Rt. Hon. W.F. Massey (Premier of New Zealand), and General The Hon. J.C. Smuts (Minister of Defence, South Africa). Back Row previously unnamed: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_Amery en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Jellicoe,_1st_Earl_Jellicoe en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Carson en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Stanley,_17th_Earl_of_Derby en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frederick_Maurice_(military_historian) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Hankey,_1st_Baron_Hankey Henry Lambert (no wiki page) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lancelot_Storr Middle Row previously unnamed: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganga_Singh en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Meston,_1st_Baron_Meston en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Cecil,_1st_Viscount_Cecil_of... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Long,_1st_Viscount_Long en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Ward en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Halsey_Perley en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Rogers_(Manitoba_politician) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Douglas_Hazen Front Row previously unnamed: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Henderson en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Milner,_1st_Viscount_Milner Source: www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/205124978 commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:The_Imperial_War_Cabinet.jpg

Robert Georges Nivelle (15 October 1856 – 22 March 1924) was a French artillery officer who served in the Boxer Rebellion, and the First World War. Nivelle was a very capable commander and organizer of field artillery at the regimental and divisional levels. In May 1916, he succeeded Philippe Pétain as commander of the French Second Army in the Battle of Verdun, leading counter-offensives that rolled back the German forces in late 1916. During these actions he and General Charles Mangin were already accused of wasting French lives. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Nivelle en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noyon

Rita Lydig (born Rita Hernandez de Alba de Acosta, October 1875– October 27, 1929) was an American socialite regarded as "the most picturesque woman in America." She was photographed by Adolf de Meyer, Edward Steichen, and Gertrude Käsebier, sculpted in alabaster by Malvina Hoffman, and was painted by Giovanni Boldini and John Singer Sargent, among others. She also wrote one novel, Tragic Mansions (Boni & Liveright, 1927), under the name Mrs Philip Lydig, a society melodrama described as "emotionally moving and appealing" by The New York Times. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rita_de_Acosta_Lydig

It is likely that this photo was taken at the Greenwich Village Garden Party in May, 1917 in Washington Square. Date on the negative seems to be 5/13/17. Mrs. George Ethridge was on the committee putting on the event. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990DE5D9123AE4... See
Thank you Richard Norton for the information about Rita Lydig. She seems to be wearing a banner that may say, "Women Suffrage...."  Was anyone able to learn anything about Mrs. George Ethridge?

Mrs. Lydig is mentioned as having attended the market at the garden party on May 22, 1917, after attending "the big suffrage sacrifice sale", so that accounts for the sash she is wearing. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=990DE5D9123AE4...

According to books.google.com/books?id=aolCAQAAIAAJ&pg=RA20-PA31#v... George Ethridge was a director of the Central Mercantile Bank. He was president of the Ethridge Company, New York. According to books.google.com/books?id=rtFCAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA19&lp... Mrs. George Ethridge was secretary of the St. Agnes Day Nursery. NYT of June 9, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9501E5D9103BEE3AB... says that Mrs. George Ethridge was Captain of the Canteen Division of the Mayor's Committee. It looks as though she was a regular among charity event organizers.

I believe Mrs. Ethridge was Julia Dinsmore Flandrau Ethridge, 1872-1941, married to George Ethridge, 1866-1941. In his obituary, Mr. Ethridge was described as the head of the New York advertising firm Ethridge Company until his retirement to Rome, N.Y., six years earlier. He had lived in N.Y.C. for 40 years. fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Rome%20NY%20Daily%20Sen... He died two weeks after Mrs. Ethridge. fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Rome%20NY%20Daily%20Sen... Their grave: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Flandr...;

Mayor Mltchel's wife got in with a young basket of carrots; Miss Tiffany gave $5 for a frankfurter and ate it- which was worth $5 more. Mortimer Loeb Schiff (June 5, 1877 – June 4, 1931), sometimes Mortimer Leo Schiff, was an American banker and notable early Boy Scouts of America (BSA) leader. His son John Mortimer Schiff was also involved with the BSA. He was also the father of Dorothy Schiff, who was the owner and publisher of the New York Post from 1939 to 1976. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mortimer_L._Schiff Dorothy Schiff (March 11, 1903 - August 30, 1989) was an owner and then publisher of the New York Post for nearly 40 years. She was a granddaughter of financier Jacob H. Schiff. Schiff was interested in social services and reform, and was involved in several welfare groups. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dorothy_Schiff

I wrote her biography for Wikipedia in 2009: Lida Louise Fleitmann Bloodgood (1894-1982), was a horsewoman in both America and Europe and an author. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lida_Fleitmann_Bloodgood

A picture clearly taken at the same time ran in the New York Tribune., May 27, 1917 in a pictorial on fashion at the Spring meet of the United Hunt Racing Association on May 12th, 1917 at Belmont Terminal, with the caption: "If you would know the last word in strictly tailored clothes, look at Helen Eilbock and Lida Fleitmann. It was to be expected that Miss Eilbock would be the first to wear one of the small sailors crowned in blue and white foulard with her sand-colored velours coat, and that Miss Fleitmann would sport an equally English-looking brown sailor with her mixed brown tweed top-coat." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-05-27/ed-...

Helen Julia Hay Whitney (March 11, 1875 – September 24, 1944) was an American poet, writer, racehorse owner/breeder, socialite, and philanthropist. She was a member by marriage of the prominent Whitney family of New York. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helen_Hay_Whitney

A picture of her clearly taken at the same event ran in the New York Tribune., May 27, 1917 in a pictorial on fashion at the Spring meet of the United Hunt Racing Association on May 12th, 1917 at Belmont Terminal, with the caption: "Of course Mrs. Payne Whitney is happy. Fire Starts from Charcoal Pot Left on the Tower Roof by Workmen. Roofers repairing the cupola on the City Hall left off work at the noon hour yesterday and neglected to put out a fire in a charcoal pot. In some manner, yet to be explained, this fire ignited some loose charcoal in one of the gutters of the roof and in a few minutes the old wooden cupola was in flames. Anna Case (October 29, 1888 – January 7, 1984) was an American soprano. She recorded with Thomas Alva Edison, who used her voice extensively in "tone tests" of whether a live audience could tell the difference between the actual singer and a recording. In addition to recordings for Edison Records on both phonograph cylinder and Diamond Disc, Case recorded for Victor and Columbia Records, and made sound film for Vitaphone. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Case
A 1915 Edison recording by Case: www.loc.gov/item/00694090/

Marie Dressler (November 9, 1868 – July 28, 1934) was a Canadian American stage and screen actress and early silent film and Depression-era film star.[2][3] Successful on stage in vaudeville and comic operas, she was also successful in film. In 1914, she was in the first full-length film comedy and later won the Academy Award for Best Actress in 1931. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marie_Dressler
see also

Possibly part of the series on the Greenwich Village Fair Although the date on the negative is 3/29/18, almost a year after the other photos, the benches and railings match some in the others, and are probably from Washington Square Park. A biography of Dressler notes that in June of 1917, she "worked as a saleslady at a Garden Party Benefit of the National League for Womens Service in Washington Square." books.google.com/books?id=zQdIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT141&d... Billboard for June 2, 1917 reported: "Marie Dressler can do more with vegetables than throw them around front of a camera She proved it when she went down on Washington Square and sold cabbage and onions for four hours at the garden party conducted by the Washington Square unit of the National League for Women's Work. A big calico apron helped create atmosphere and true to huckster tradition she shrank not from asking twice the market price for her goods But unlike the bona fide lady of the pushcart she got what she asked." books.google.com/books?id=XaoiAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA8-PA5&... The Washington, D.C. Times reported, on May 23, 1917: "VEGETABLE PARTY RAISES BIG FUND New York People Help Woman's National Service League. NEW YORK. May 23. Five thousand society, near-society, and non-society folk paid their way into a Washington Square garden party with raw vegetables which they later bought back at prices that even the war never can force. Wherefore, the Woman's National Service League's campaign fund is richer by several thousand dollars today. Mayor Mltchel's wife got in with a young basket of carrots; Miss Tiffany gave $5 for a frankfurter and ate it- which was worth $5 more. Marie Dressler auctioned off a bouquet of cabbages, onions, string beans, and garlic tied with red. white, and blue baby ribbon." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1917-05-23/ed-...

Thanks for this excellent research Art Siegel. I agree that this photo was most likely taken at the same event in support of the National League for Women's Service in 1917.  We'll add some of the information to the record the next time we update.

William Gibbs McAdoo, Jr. (October 31, 1863 – February 1, 1941) was an American lawyer and statesman. McAdoo was a leader of the Progressive movement who played a major role in the two presidential administrations of Woodrow Wilson. He was Wilson's campaign manager in 1912; he married Wilson's daughter, and served as his secretary of the Treasury. He was primarily responsible for financing the American side of World War I, providing large loans to the Allies, and running the troubled railroad system inside the United States. He was a leading contender for his party's presidential nomination in 1920 and 1924 and served as Senator from California as a Democrat. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo

William Gibbs McAdoo, III (1895 - 1960) www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=9068694 "As an ensign, he was designated a Naval Aviator (# 236) in 1918. He was discharged from active service in 1921 with the rank of Lt JG." He was the son of William Gibbs McAdoo, Jr. (October 31, 1863 – February 1, 1941), at that time Secretary of the Treasury en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Gibbs_McAdoo

"William Gibbs McAdoo, jr., besides being the namesake of his father, also bears a striking resemblance to him. He, too, was educated at St. Paul's School and at Princeton. He had just started in business when the war clouds gathered and he enlisted in the aviation section of the Naval Militia and has just begun a course of training at the Bay Shore training camp." From "Sons of Cabinet Officers in U. S. Fighting Forces", Evening star., June 03, 1917, Page 2, col. 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1917-06-03/ed-...

The Balfour visit : how America received her distinguished guest ; and the significance of the conferences in the archive.org/stream/balfourvisithowa00townuoft#page/14/mod... indicates that his ship arrived in Halifax, Nova Scotia. His party immediately "crossed to St. John, where a train awaited them and took them to the tiny village of McAdam, just beyond the International Bridge." An American Reception Committee, including Breckinridge Long, Major General Leonard Wood, and Colonel Mackie met them at the border, and the parties traveled to Washington by train. Balfour met with President Wilson on April 23, 1917. Arrival in New York was on May 11, 1917.

Another Bain photo of Campbell, in the LOC collection: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2005696170/ "On 7 March 1917 and while the US was "on the brink" of entering the war - they declared war just under a month later on 2 April 1917 - the NLWS established a training program for female wireless operators at Hunter College in New York. The course director was Edna Owen (generally credited under her husband's name, Mrs Herbert Sumner Owen) who was also chairman of the NLWS's wireless division and founder of the Women's Radio Corps, a branch of the US Army Signal Corps. The first student to graduate was Ms Helen Campbell, shown right, with another early graduate being Elise Van R. Owen, shown in a June 1917 newspaper article testing a receiving set at the wireless school at Hunter College. Women were trained to use wireless telegraph instruments to work for the US government or private companies and to take the place of male wireless operators who had gone to war." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_League_for_Women%27s_Service

Women's Work in Wartime archive.org/stream/cu31924013938703#page/n53/mode/2up/sea... lists a number of technical institutes and colleges in London where munitions training was available.

The Imperial War Museum has some posters online for the L.C.C munitions training programs: www.duxford.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/28479 "LONDON COUNTY COUNCIL WOMEN WANTED FOR MUNITION WORK OFFER OF FREE TRAINING WITH MAINTENANCE CLASSES CONDUCTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE MINISTRY OF MUNITIONS Instruction is given in general machine work or acetylene welding. Special attention is given to lathe work, drilling, milling, shaping, profiling and capstan-lathe work for munition factories. Workers are allocated to the centres nearest their homes, and are required to attend for 8 hours daily. Payment at the rate of 25/- per week is made from enrolment: those who show ability and pass a medical examination are allocated to special courses, after the first week. Caps and overalls are supplied for the use of women students who accept maintenance allowance. All instruments and materials are provided free of charge. Particulars and application forms in regard to these classes may be obtained from the Education Officer, L.C.C. Education Offices, Victoria Embankment, " www.duxford.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/31389

the princess: "Princess Alexandra, 2nd Duchess of Fife, GCStJ (Alexandra Victoria Alberta Edwina Louise; née Duff; later Princess Arthur of Connaught; 17 May 1891 – 26 February 1959) was a member of the British Royal Family, a granddaughter of King Edward VII. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Princess_Alexandra,_2nd_Duchess_of_... The WSTC on the women's uniforms stands for Women Signallers Territorial Corps. They appear to be holding wrapped-up signal flags and their insignia are crossed signal flags. James Lauren Ford (1854 - 1928), humorist and author brookhavensouthhaven.org/hamletpeople/tng/getperson.php?p... In 1917 he was president of the Porcupine Publishing Corporation, s. scripophily.net/popuco19.html Detail of the photo: www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05/17246989708/
Thanks B-59, we'll add his full name to the catalog record.

The Porcupine's credo, from "The Editor" magazine, May 19, 1917: "The Porcupine 211 West Thirty third Street New York NY James L Ford editor writes "The Porcupine will print informative and satirical articles and stories of moderate length. I do not care for anything more than eight hundred words. I am on the look out for new writers of unexploited talent and I will remark that they are as scarce as hen's teeth." The first number of The Porcupine has just appeared dated May 1917. In the first number the editor has the following announcements. "In this the first number of the magazine that bears his name the Porcupine comes out into the open quip jest and pleasing casuistry on his lips but in his heart a grim purpose that will seek expression through his quills For he has come into the arena to do his bit in the great battle for human liberty, a battle in which our nation is destined to play a part worthy of its most splendid traditions. The Porcupine believes that he has chosen a singularly opportune moment for his appearance on the scene. The wave of patriotic feeling that has been slowly gathering headway since the Lusitania murders is sweeping over the entire country, submerging the weakened Pacifists, driving from their holes the plotting reservists, the traitorous filibusters and pro Germans, and others of the reptilian species, and throwing its whole weight into the fight. It is on that great wave that the Porcupine launches his frail craft." books.google.com/books?id=j15CAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA462&l...
Ford recounted the 11 month life of The Porcupine in this memoir. It folded when his main investor committed suicide. www.forgottenbooks.com/readbook_text/Forty-Odd_Years_in_t...

While I can't find any issues of The Porcupine online, some of its satire, was reproduced in a 1918 newspaper. His lampooning of socialites who looked for photo opportunities to display themselves as patriots fits well into the Bain 1917 releases. "The reader knows the type and is familiar with the schedule:— How Mrs ____ is helping Hoover to prepare prunes. Mrs ____ , in fetching Oriental dress, tells how money can be contributed to aid the Albanians. How Mrs _____ looks in khaki. Worn at a recent masquerade given at her residence." paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=AG...

This photo was printed in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.), May 20, 1917, with the caption: "Women Recruiting. Women are doing their bit in New York to speed up recruiting. Mrs. Charles Farnam and Mrs. Franklin P. Adams recently started out in an automobile and within an hour had got 23 young men from the Wall-street district headed for the recruiting station. Later they got eight more in Times Square. Mrs. Farnam was the first woman to enter reconquered Serbian . territory with the troops of the allies. She was under fire with the troops for six hours and has received medals from the Serbian government for bravery." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-05-20/ed-1/se... Mrs. Charles Farman was Ruth Stanley Farnam, widow since 1909 of Charles H. Farman. She was a fervent supporter of Serbia's war efforts and was made a sergeant in the Royal Serbian Cavalry. She also lectured in support of Serbia throughout the U.S. She remarried 25 Feb 1928, to Baron Raymond de Luze, a wine merchant of Saumur, France. b Patchogue, LI, NY 11 Sept 1873 ; d Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, NY 7 Dec 1956, age 83. She remarried 25 Feb 1928, to Baron Raymond de Luze, a wine merchant of Saumur, France. books.google.com/books?id=BVQwAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA692&l... www.genealogy.com/forum/surnames/topics/farnham/448/ Franklin P. Adams was a famous newspaper writer of the era. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franklin_Pierce_Adams His wife from 1904 to 1924 was the former Minna Schwartze of Wyoming. books.google.com/books?id=QKVsrU-WPP4C&pg=PA1&lpg... books.google.com/books?id=coybBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA18&lp...
