en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patriots%27_Day The Wake Up America Day celebrations began at midnight with a reenactment of Paul Revere's ride made by a young woman. Jean Earle Mohle, dressed as a Continental soldier, rode south through the streets of Manhattan summoning the men of America to respond to their country's call (New York Times on April 19, 1917) She appears on the poster for the event: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton/17147335309/] www.loc.gov/pictures/item/00653124/ Lots of coverage in the New York Times: query.nytimes.com/search/sitesearch/?action=click&con...

In the NYT article she is described as suffragist query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E05E6DA153AE4... The correct name is Jean Earl Moehle (or Möhle), see e.g. - "Cities across the country planned parades, meetings and demonstrations, along with midnight church bells and horseback-riding messengers dressed as Paul Revere trotting through the streets. In Manhattan, Miss Jean Earl Moehle played the part of the well-known patriot." nationalheritagemuseum.typepad.com/library_and_archives/2... - newspaperarchives.vassar.edu/cgi-bin/vassar?a=d&d=lit... (1903) - www.motorcities.org/Story/Spotlight+on+Women+of+the+Maxwe... "The Maxwell Car Company organized the “Maxwell Women Sales Bureau” which included some of the most talented women in the industry. Some of them were Crystal Eastman, Alice Carpenter, who was the field organizer, Mary Garrett Hay, and Jean Earl Moehle. Jean Moehle was a new saleswomen who helped demonstrate that not only could a woman understand machinery, but she could handle it as well." - Eat My Dust: Early Women Motorists, p. 78 books.google.ch/books?id=bbuOiq0YEKYC&pg=PA78&lpg...
See also the Daily capital journal. (Salem, Or.) 1903-1919, April 19, 1917, Image 6, col. 2, "NINE PAUL REVERES" oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn99063957/1917-04-19/ed-1/se...

Mislabeled as British Embassy, but actually (former Treasury Secretary) Francis MacVeigh's mansion on 16th St. N.W., which he loaned to the arriving British War Commission as its residence. In 1921, Mexico purchased it as its embassy and altered the entry by adding a portico. It is now the Mexican Cultural Institute. A photo of her from 1920 is in England's National Portrait Gallery with the caption "Julia Hoyt (née Robbins) (1897-1955), Actress; former wife of Lydig Hoyt, and later wife of Louis Calhern. New York society hostess Julia Robbins married Lydig Hoyt in June 1914 and began her career as an amateur actress after claiming the 'eternal round of luncheons, teas, bridge, and theatres was driving her mad'. The year after Hoppé made this portrait Hoyt began work as a film actress and in 1921 made her screen debut opposite Norma Talmadge in The Wonderful Thing. " www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp123365/julia-h...

Halstead Dorey (1874-1946) eventually became a Brigadier General himself: "Maj. Gen. Halstead Dorey commanded the US Army, Pacific from 1934-1935. A graduate of the US Military Academy in 1897, he saw action in the Spanish-American War in the Philippines and in the subsequent Philippine Insurrection. He also took part in multiple campaigns during World War I. As commander of the 4th Infantry in France from May to October of 1918, Gen. Dorey participated in the battles of Aisne, Aisne-Marne, Champaigne-Marne, St. Mihiel, and Meuse-Argonne. He earned the Distinguished Service Cross, Distinguished Service Medal, Silver Star, and Purple Heart. He retired in 1936 and died on 19 June 1946. "Fairfax Harrison (full name Reginald Fairfax Harrison:[2] March 13, 1869 – February 2, 1938) was an American lawyer, businessman, and writer. The son of the secretary to Confederate President Jefferson Davis, Harrison studied law at Yale University and Columbia University before becoming a lawyer for the Southern Railway Company in 1896. By 1906 he was Southern's vice-president of finance, and in 1907 he helped secure funding to keep the company solvent. In 1913 he was elected president of Southern, where he instituted a number of reforms in the way the company operated." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairfax_Harrison

The building at the left, behind the streetcar, says "H.F. Rahe 1148". The Henry F. Rahe Cafe (per the 1917 city directory) was at 1148 St. Nicholas Avenue in Manhattan, which is between 167th and 168th Streets. So this shot is taken looking east along St. Nicholas, with the corner of 167th Street at right. The Navy probably set this up to take advantage of the huge crowds attending Billy Sunday's New York revival (held April through June, 1917), which was taking place just steps away, at his newly-built New York Tabernacle, at 168th and Broadway. In the Bain shot below of the crowds at Sunday's tabernacle, you can see 1148 St. Nicholas and the Uneeda Biscuit sign at the upper right.

Sgt. Gibson was the army recruiting officer at Macon, Georgia where the Yankees trained before the season in 1917. He was assigned by the Army as a drillmaster for the team. On Opening Day, April 11, 1917, the Times headline read: "Donovan's Soldiers Do Military Stunts for 16,000 Fans, but Their Baseball Is Poor. GEN. WOOD REVIEWS DRILL " query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9902E7DD153AE4...

In the front is Major Dorey of Gen. Woods' staff, flanked by the team's owners. From the New York Tribune: "ln the major matter of military science, the Yankees, swinging in column of squads across the field, won a popular victory that was of much more consequence than a baseball game. Just before the bell rang for the Yankee practice period Manager Donovan gave a signal and the men scurried to the clubhouse. The band struck up a quickstep and then, out of the clubhouse into which the baseball players disappeared stepped the neatest and nattiest looking infantry platoon that ever marched. The men wore the white home uniform of the Yankee baseball team. They carried their bats on their shoulders. But it would have taken the quartermaster department only a few short minutes to put them into the olive drab and to hand them Springfield rifles, and they would have passed for a platoon of regular army infantrymen. Major Dorey, of Major General Woods' staff, let on the platoon. He was flanked of one side by the martial figure of Captain Tillinghast L'Hommedieu Huston and on the other by the scarcely less martial figure of Colonel Jacob Ruppert. Sergeant William Donovan (Wild Bill Donovan) acted as guide. [...] After doing light military calisthenics with their bats the Yankees were dismissed by their drill sergeant and became mere civilians and baseball player! once more." Robert Lansing (October 17, 1864 – October 30, 1928) was an American lawyer and politician who served as Legal Advisor to the State Department at the outbreak of World War I, and then as United States Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson from 1915 to 1920. Before U.S. involvement in the war, Lansing vigorously advocated in favor of the principles of freedom of the seas and the rights of neutral nations. He later advocated U.S. participation in World War I, negotiated the Lansing–Ishii Agreement with Japan in 1917 and was a member of the American Commission to Negotiate Peace at Paris in 1919. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Lansing

The Capitol was not regularly illuminated until 1917, starting with the 2d inauguration of Wilson in early March. From Practical Engineer magazine, July 15, 1917: "The Federal Capitol illuminated against the sombre shadows of night, at this critical moment in our history, the inspiring white dome of our Capitol at Washington high above the Federal City stands resplendent in rays of shining light, a radiant monument to freedom and democracy. The plans for illuminating the Capitol dome were perfected for the recent inauguration of President Wilson and the spectacular results were so satisfactory that the system was made permanent." more technical details of the lighting system at: books.google.com/books?id=3Bw8AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA585&l...

Rear Admiral Bradley Allen Fiske (June 13, 1854 - April 6, 1942) was an officer in the United States Navy who was noted as a technical innovator. During his long career, Fiske invented more than a hundred and thirty electrical and mechanical devices, with both Naval and civilian uses, and wrote extensively on technical and professional issues; The New Yorker called him "one of the notable naval inventors of all time." One of the earliest to understand the revolutionary possibilities of naval aviation, he wrote a number of books of important effect in gaining a wider understanding of the modern Navy by the public. For inventing the rangefinder, he was awarded the Elliott Cresson Medal of The Franklin Institute in 1891. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bradley_A._Fiske

This crane existed in 1907 already, s. photo in the Daily press., March 24, 1907, Image 21 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045830/1907-03-24/ed-...

And this 1900 article is illustrated by a photo of Hercules in 1898: "In view of the attention which the management has given to the question of the handling of material it is quite natural that the equipment of derricks and cranes should constitute one of the most interesting features of the Newport News yard. First place must be given of course to the 150 ton revolving derrick Hercules. The derrick jib is capable of having its outer end raised or lowered thus giving to the hoisting blocks which depend vertically therefrom a movement of rotation about the center of the derrick, and also one of translation in and out from the center. With the outer end of the jib in its lowest position the hoisting blocks will, on rotation of the derrick, describe the circumference of a circle 207 feet in diameter; with the jib in its highest position the diameter of the circle described is 88 feet. Thus the derrick may operate on weights lying anywhere between these two circles as boundaries. The maximum load of 150 tons can be handled only within a ring the maximum and minimum diameters of which are 147 and 88 feet respectively, but weights not exceeding 70 tons may be handled throughout the entire field of operations. The maximum elevations above mean high water,, for the hoisting blocks, are 118 and 69 feet respectively in the high and lower positions of the jib. The derrick is revolved by duplicate sets of machinery. books.google.com/books?id=Eb1MAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA501&l...

An advertisement in the "New York Herald" for Sunday, March 24, 1917, page 16 (fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%2014/New%20York%20NY%20Herald...) listed Ethel Barrymore as "Europa", Mrs. Oliver Harriman as "America", and Mme. Frances Alda as "Columbia". Ethel Barrymore should be well-known to everyone. Mrs. Oliver Harriman is better known as Grace Harriman, Jr. (nee Carley). She later wrote a well-known book about etiquette. Frances Alda (31 May 1879– 18 September 1952) was a New Zealand-born, Australian-raised operatic soprano. This peformance was a tableaux, part of a "Big Triple Patriotic Bill" featuring the motion picture "Uncle Sam Awake" (introduced by James W. Gerard, U.S. Ambassador to Germany); a series of musical performances headlined by Eddie Cantor; an address by New York City Mayor John Purroy Mitchel; and an apperance by Douglas Fairbanks. The event was at the Hippodrome in New York City. The Junior Patriots of America (chaired by Hamilton Fish, Jr.) sponsored the show to benefit military preparedness.

She was 77," query.nytimes.com/mem/archive/pdf?res=9B02E0D61238E532A25... Alexandra Feodorovna (Russian: Императрица Александра Фёдоровна, Imperatritsa Aleksandra Fyodorovna) (6 June 1872 – 17 July 1918), was Empress consort of Russia as the spouse of Nicholas II, the last Emperor of the Russian Empire. Born as Alix of Hesse and by Rhine, was granddaughter of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom. Upon being received into the Russian Orthodox Church, she was given the name Alexandra Feodorovna and in 2000 she was canonized as Saint Alexandra the Passion Bearer. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandra_Feodorovna

She clearly had an amazing array of jewelry. See, e.g., www.alexanderpalace.org/palace/aexpenses.html

It looks as though the tiara survived and is in the first photo in this blog post: maries-jewels-royals.blogspot.ca/2014/02/russian-imperial... The tiara was apparently made by Bolin, a court jeweler.

The photo at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexandra_Feodorovna_%28Alix_of_Hes... is in the same dress and jewels. That is another Bain photo. Someone other than LoC has dated it 1908 and identified the photographer as Boasson and Eggler St. Petersburg Nevsky 24. That date is found on a copy signed by the empress seen at www.romanovrussia.com/Signature_Autograph_Photograph_Empr... Her husband abdicated in March 1917. From the Wikipedia article: "On 12 March soldiers sent to suppress the rioting crowds mutinied and joined the rebellion, thus providing the spark to ignite the February Revolution (like the later October Revolution of November 1917, the Russian Revolutions of 1917 get their names due to the Old Style calendar). Soldiers and workers set up the "Petrograd Soviet" of 2,500 elected deputies while the Duma declared a Provisional Government on 13 March. Alexander Kerensky was a key player in the new regime. The Duma informed the tsar that day that he must abdicate. In an effort to put an end to the uprising in the capital, Nicholas tried to get to St Petersburg by train from army headquarters at Mogiliev. The route was blocked so he tried another way. His train was stopped at Pskov where, after receiving advice from his generals, he first abdicated the throne for himself and later, on seeking medical advice, for himself and his son the tsarevich Alexei. Alexandra was now in a perilous position as the wife of the deposed tsar, hated by the Russian people. Nicholas finally was allowed to return to the Alexander Palace at Tsarskoe Selo where he was placed under arrest with his family. Despite the fact he was a first cousin of both Nicholas and Alexandra, George V refused to allow them to evacuate to the United Kingdom, as he was alarmed by their unpopularity in his country and the potential repercussions to his own throne."

Arnaldo Casella Tamburini (1885 - 1936), s. www.askart.com/AskART/artists/biography.aspx?searchtype=B...
He took his own life on September 12, 1936 in Chicago, Illinois when he jumped from a second story window at St. Luke's Hospital where he had been hospitalized for mental illness.
NYT story on his suicide: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9404E6DF143DE33BB...

A short biographical sketch from January, 1918: Brooklyn Daily Eagle, January 20, 1918 Count Tambourini To Be Guest of Honor "Count Casella Tamburini, who is to be guest of honor of La Boheme, an art society, at a reception tendered to him by La Boheme, with members of the Brooklyn Society of Artists and of the Allied Arts Association, today, January 20, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Brewster, 310 Washington avenue, is a young artist who recently joined the Washington Square colony. He was for more than three years court painter to the Royal Family of Italy. As a boy he started art work in the Florentine Royal Academy of Art and at 13 was graduated into the nude school, thereafter studying under his father, Arnaldo Tamburini, court painter for King Humbert and Queen Margharita. Count Tamburini won his first prize in portrait painting at a national exhibition in Florence with a portrait of his mother. King Vittorio Emmanuele then made him court painter. Among portraits of the King of Italy that he painted were those presented to the Shah of Persia, to the Emperor of Japan and to the French Government on the occasion of the fiftieth anniversary of Italian independence. Since coming to America Count Tamburini painted a portrait of Cardinal Farley and also large compositions among the steel workers of Pittsburg. They are on exhibition in the Florentine Royal Academy. He does not look for a boom in European art immediately following the war. If it had been a short war of quick conquest he believes that the pictorial art would have received a decided impetus. He believes, however, that a new school of art will spring up in Italy after the war, an art in which the common people will express their voices." Count Tamburini's informant in Italy tells him that Germany has sent a commission into Northern Italy with the ostensible purpose of protecting art treasures in Venice, but, as a matter of fact, the art body as well as the army believes that Germans invaded Italy for the purpose of confiscation, as they have done in Belgium, and that, should they gain Venice, it will be despoiled of its treasures. Hence the implacable hate that is now making the Italians fight so courageously. " fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20E... A self portrait: www.artnet.com/artists/arnaldo-casella-tamburini-jr/self-...

Another biographical sketch (though the painting accompanying it appears to be by his father): "Count Tamburini was born of noble birth in Florence, Italy in 1885. At the age of fifteen he won a national art contest and Victor Emmanuel III, King of Italy, commissioned him to paint his portrait. The young artist was following in his father's footsteps as court painter to the Italian throne. He became an artist of international acclaim and in 1901 set out for Canada to paint the Prime Minister, Sir Wilfred Laurier. The following year he traveled to America to paint the Archbishop of New York. These journeys started a lifetime of travel, painting some of world's most illustrious people of the time, including Queen Marie of Romania and Czar Nicholas II and his family. Tamburini married miniature painter Dolores Dolja Dunifer in 1914 and the young couple settled in New York, although they continued to travel extensively. Tamburini himself died from an accidental death in 1936. As well as portraits, Tamburini painted allegorical compositions and landscapes." www.mylearning.org/portraits/p-601/

In 1928, an Australian newspaper account as he and his wife arrived there (they arrived in July, 1928): " COUNT TAMBURINI. A COURT PAINTER. ARRIVES WITH PORTRAIT OF THE POPE. The portrait of the Pope, which will be an important accessory in ceremonies at the Eucharistic Congress, arrived in Sydney last night by the steamer Aorangi. Count Cas- sela Tamburini, the artist, personally super- intended the transport of the picture, which he painted in the 16th Chapel at Rome. The Count Tamburini, vivacious and enthusiastic, is a notable portraitist in Europe, but he is looking forward to his stay in Sydney prin- cipally because he has heard that it is a paradise for landscape painters. He ex- pects to do a lot of work here. He has painted numerous portraits in the Courts, or late Courts, of Europe. The King of Italy has sat for three separate pictures, and Mussolini granted him the first sitting he ever gave. His portrait of the Queen of Roumania excited considerable interest. He is accompanied by the Countess Cassela | Tamburini." The Sydney Morning Herald 20 July 1928 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16480819#pstart1202343
His portrait of Will Rogers: www.ellensplace.net/philosph.html

A longer, and somewhat starstruck profile of the couple in Australia: TOURISTS. Count and Countess Tamburini. (BY YETTA ROSENBLOOM.) The Count Arnaldo Casella Tamburini, and his charming South American wife, came as tourists to visit Sydney during the month of October. Being previously engaged upon the portraits of the Pope Pius XI, at the Sistlne Chapel in Rome, this world-famed artist gained the appreciation of the Holy Father on his results. So, with the sanction and commendation of the Vatican, two remarkable portraits were brought to Sydney. Unfor- tunately the Customs officials intervened, and thus only the smaller portrait of the Pope was placed at St. Mary's Cathedral during the Eucharistic Congress. Much interest was aroused, as the likeness was wonderful. As- tonishing also was the fact that the artist had gained his place at the early age of 13, in the Art Academy of Italy. Then his por- trait of his beautiful mother was considered remarkable. So the heritage of fourteen cen- turies of art was handed down. The Countess Casella, Timburini's mother. is a very talented musician. She also com- poses. It was naturally an experiment when her eldest son brought to the ancient palace In Floronce an American wife, who regarded with wide-open eyes the famous carvings and antiques of one of the oldest Roman families. The young wife shivered as she walked over the wnite marble floors and peep- ed through a vista of spacious reception rooms. Musty with age, and crumbling in their cellars amongst the old vintages, the new Countess unlocked coffers full of won- drous Persian shawls of Paisley design, which bore the names of the artists of a bygone age. Picture the dismay of the old Countess Tam- burini when she learned that cables to the United States had been sent to bring over modern lighting equipment and steam heat for their sumptuous hut chilly surround- ings. It was thus that old Rome awakened to the advent of the modern school. It was not an easy task to reconstruct a Roman household, but the experiment was-successful for all parties. INDUSTRY COUNTS. Industry counts iIn Italy, and both the Count and Countess Tamburini have never a mo- ment to spare. They live every minute. As a relaxation from the easel the Count likes to ride to hounds, or have a game of ten- nis, or go swimming. Then the Countess packs up her tubes of oils, and wanders forth to a public hospital, where she seeks out some cripple. She answers to the name of Dolia, and likes to read some good story to a bed-weary patient. She is always en- deavouring to do someone a good turn in a quiet way. Both these modest and really humble, personages of the nobility stroll forth around the city, and learn much of our mode of living. "Some years ago now," the Countess said, "we decided to settle down in an apartment house in New York, so we transplanted many of our antiques to the mod- ern dwelling. Massive furnishings and rare old brocades were taken over, and these, with the old wood carvings over the doors, so fascinated the elite of New York that studio parties became a craze. I had just finished a delightful miniature of my husband on ivory, which was drying in the studio, when some of our visitors took a fancy to it, and it disappeared; so did my jewels, and finally that settled our New York domicile. We packed up and wandered forth to Boston, where Mr. Clarence W. Barron, of the 'Bos- ton News,' and the 'Boston Weekly,' placed his town house and yacht at our disposal. "It was whilst aboard the boat that the busy man sat for his painting, which was greatly prized. Also so many interesting people who were his guests desired to be painted. Signora Galli Curci and her husband were guests at the same house party, and we had the best of music. As Count Tamburini plays and sings he adds gaiety to every party. I have to drive him sometimes to settle down to his painting, because the society beauties of the old and new world lure him from his art. But when Arnaldo Tamburini decides to make a masterpiece he excludes himself from everyone. "Sometimes six months elapse and when he returns from his exclusion I can see by his face that he has achieved something that has given him the necessary satisfaction. Then he is loth to sell his work. It was thus, when in such a mood, he painted Mussolini. Never had that untiring leader even been photo- graphed. Count Tamburini was insistent up- on permission to observe him in his study, intense with the emotion of a great resolve. So the artist made his portrait in oils, and that picture now hangs in a room to itself at the famous Academy of Arts In New York, Where Sir Joseph Devine has an unwritten law that only the old masters can adorn his walls. This is in itself an achievement for a comparatively young man." Intensely proud is the beautiful Countess. She comes from an old South American fam- ily, and studied art as a girl. She thus is at one with her husband, and has the same ideals. They both treasure antiques. They delight in colour. Each vies with the other in love of the tones of deepest tangerine and yellow; but neither shows the other any work until it is completed. KEEN DISAPPOINTMENT. It was a keen disappointment to them to arrive in Sydney and find that our Customs authorities made an exhibition prohibitive. It was Count Tamburini's desire to exhibit on a grand scale. That would have meant distributing many thousands of pounds in ad- vertising; and there would have been other expenses. "Why cannot Australia adopt the American law? What I desire to say," urged the Count, "to those interested in art here in Australia is that if a foreign artist could bring in works of art duty free for just one year for exhibition purposes, how much more interesting it would be. There would be a better incentive for artists, and the pub- lic would gain more in knowledge." "What we find lacking in Sydney," the Countess continued, "Is the right type of apartment houses. Here we paid more than in New York for a flat where comparisons were against it in every requisite. That is not agreeable for tourists. We came with the intention of staying here a long period. We proposed also to ask some of our very distinguished friends to join us. But the high rents, the cost of living, and the excessive duty on our portraits, which are essential for us to have with us always, settled the matter. We do not consider it advisable to remain here very much longer unless, of course, the law changes, and our goods and chattels can come in at less cost." 'We have no quarrel with a Government that excludes commodities that can be pro- cured here. But what have you in the way of antiques? One frame on the portraits we brought into Sydney cannot be priced. It is so old, and so very valuable. Why exclude a curiosity? "Our desire, " added the Count, "was to make the most of everything and enjoy the great hospitality that every one bestows on strangers here But when I came, nearly two months were wasted on tie doorsteps of the Government officials, awaiting their edict about my paintings. It is all very disheartening for a hard-working artist. When I decide to paint a portrait, I never know how long it will take me. I may achieve my ideal in one hour. Another sitter may take me months of really hard work. It is a joy to dabble with my colours. I favour yellow tones. "When the ex-Queen Marie of Roumania decided that I should paint her portrait we were at sea. The ship rolled and tossed, and how we all enjoyed searching for my tubes of colour. That painting was sold to benefit the poor children of Roumania. " The physology of art is in itself a great study, and both the Count and Countess Timburini have the inborn love for humanity that expresses itself in their studies. Each make a point of achieving what they desire. Their determination and self-denial are very remarkable Opals are the delight of the Countess, whose desire it is to see the opal fields here. The count loves to cook a meal while his beautiful wife remakes a Paris gown. She enjoys a good day's sewing and has that artistry of line which astounds even the friends who know she sews for pastime. But it takes such an enthusiastic wife to urge such a man to do still better things for art. To them money means nothing. They have always had means to study, and to linger where and when they desired. No greater portrait painter lives to-day that Count Tamburlini. Sargent he considered was the world's greatest. He does not boast, he enjoys his fame. He knows his worth to the art world. Tamburlini at the moment is painting at the sheep-shear- ing sheds in Victoria, ere leaving for the United States. There the newly-elected Presi- dent will sit for his portrait. That is their life, and they enjoy it." The Sydney Morning Herald Saturday 1 December 1928 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16513415#pstart1198878
The Count was still in Australia in January, 1929 and there is a lengthy illustrated interview with him from the Melbourne Advocate: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/171654702

Batumi (Georgian: ბათუმი, formerly known as Batum) is a seaside city on the Black Sea coast and capital of Adjara, an autonomous republic in southwest Georgia. With a population of 190,000 (2013 census), Batumi serves as an important port and a commercial center. It is situated in a subtropical zone, rich in agricultural produce such as citrus fruit and tea. While industries of the city include shipbuilding, food processing, and light manufacturing, most of its economy revolves around tourism. Since 2010, the face of the city has been transformed by the construction of new high-rise landmark buildings and the renovation of the Old Town. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batumi

The long cylindrical basket on the right is an eel trap.  The sailing boat is a wherry.  Normally used to transport goods this one has a cabin is is used as a pleasure boat.  Note the ladies with parasols.
Is the hut a boat too, or maybe something set up to fish out of a hole in the bottom?

Not a boat, nor with a hole in the floor.  The boat tied to the bank is for the eel fisher to go out and empty  his traps which are laid in the channels where eels are found.  The hut provides working space to store tools, repair equipment and sort eels.  The eels for sale are transported in a hessian sack.

It indeed seems to me that the hut is built in a hull and can swim. Looks like it's at the same spot in this 1883 photo: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:The_Pembroke_Castle_(1883).jpg "The Pembroke Castle, the second ship of that name, was a steamer of 3 946 tons. She came into service in 1883 and was probably best known for a cruise she undertook to Norway and Sweden shortly after her delivery in September 1883. Her owner, Sir Donald Currie, entertained 29 members of Europe's royal families, as well as Prime Minister Gladstone and Alfred Lord Tennyson, on board. Gladstone received a royal reprimand from Queen Victoria for his part in the affair, since he had not first sought her permission to absent himself from his office. She was sold to the Turkish government in 1906. The Pembroke Castle made only one round trip to the Cape." www.sahistory.org.za/list-south-african-shipwrecks Apparently, Currie's Castle Line (by then the Union-Castle Line) sold her to Turkey in 1906 and she became Bezmi-Alem: "Pembroke Castle (2)18831900 transferred to Union-Castle Mail SS Co., 1906 sold to Turkey, renamed Bezmi-Alem." www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/castle.shtml According to this site, " Sold to Turkish Government 1906 and sunk by Russian warships 1915 off Samsun, Turkey. " diogel.cyngor.gwynedd.gov.uk/DATRhagorol/RhestrEitem.aspx... See Cross Channel and Short Sea Ferries: An Illustrated History by Lord Ambrose Greenway books.google.com/books?id=qBdvBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT113&l... Lydia was a Lynx-class steamer built in 1890, running between the Channel Islands and Weymouth.
swanq: thanks for finding more information about the ship.  We may add some more information to the record.

Correction to swanq's Comment: No, Lydia was the second of the Frederica class Southern Railway steamers that ran between the Channel Islands & France and Southampton IN COMPETITION WITH the Great Western Railway Lynx class ships that ran out of Weymouth. The Frederica class comprised Frederica, Lydia and Stella, and the Lynx class out of Weymouth was made up by Lynx, Antelope and Gazelle.
And this image depicts Lydia leaving Southampton's cross channel dock, the South Western Hotel (and Railway Station) being clearly visible background left.

I should also have said what a splendid image this is!  And I have a correction to my own Comment:  Lydia was actually a London & South Western Railway steamer, and she was sold by that company just a few weeks before  it became (part of) Southern Railway.
I can also add that, although I have no record of my grandfather having commanded the Lydia (as he did many other of the L&SWR and Southern Railway steamers out of Southampton), he would almost certainly have served aboard her.
WT159: Thanks for the clarification on the Lydia. We will add more information to the image description. Its fascinating that your grandfather served on this steamer.

A reminiscence of St. Anne's Convalescent home, damaged in WWII bombing, now demolished: "But as the Bombs fell on the night of l7th/l8th june,l941 The St.Annes Convalescent Home situated between St. Annes road and Sands Lane,Bridlington had been badly bombed together with its Church on site,which Percy and his family had visited over many years making friends with residents and Raymond his son had played the Church Organ at various services there on many occasions, the convalescent home and church premises stood empty it was not demolished till the l960s era now replaced by sheltered housing bungalows." www.bbc.co.uk/history/ww2peopleswar/stories/04/a4020904.s... Some information on the building of the Home, from 1878 "ST ANNE'S ORPHANAGE AND CONVALESCENT HOSPITAL BRIDLINGTON QUAY THESE premises when finished are intended to accommodate 150 inmates at present only a portion is completed. As the building has been erected by public subscriptions the funds did not allow of the whole scheme which includes a church being carried out at once.[...] The building fronts south and west the main elevation being 150 feet long faced with local red stock bricks having coloured brick strings and arches. Stone is very sparingly used on account of the expense; the roof is covered with blue slates and red ridges. Special care has been taken with the lighting and ventilation The present portion has been carried out by Mr THOS GRAY as sole contractor at a cost of about 3,800 L from the designs and under the superintendence of Mr. J. EARNSHAW architect of Bridlington Quay. The amount required to complete the Orphanage exclusive of furnishing is about 2,000 L. The institution so far as at present completed was opened July 1 the number of beds being 82." books.google.com/books?id=e35JwYPsObsC&pg=PA364&l... Still around, and a Grade II listed building: "Town hall. 1882. By JB Pearce after a competition. Red brick laid in Flemish bond and with terracotta details and sandstone dressings. Slate roofs. Built round a narrow courtyard. Queen Anne style. EXTERIOR: 2 storeys rising to 3 in the tower. Asymmetrical entrance front to the north-west. 7-window range. Rusticated ground floor and string courses between the floors. To the left are 3 bays of cross casements fitted with plate-glass horned sashes. The first-floor windows have 2 transoms. Small pediments in the balustraded parapet. These bays have paired pilasters right and left. The centre bay has one 3-light cross casement (with sashes) to each of its 3 floors. The right-hand 3 bays contain the round-arched principal entrance and two 2-light cross casements as before. Paired pilasters separate the first-floor cross casements which have the double transoms and now round heads. Swags in the parapet. A tower, square on plan, rises through 2 storeys to an ogeed lantern: open round arches over clock faces; glazed lantern. The south-west facade faces the river: symmetrical; 8 bays plus closing bays right and left. Cross casements fitted with sashes as before. Garlanded parapet and central segmental pediment. Hipped roofs with flat. INTERIOR: the entrance hall has pairs of panelled baluster piers on high plinths alternating with single piers running down the centre and attached as pilasters to the walls. Modified Ionic capitals. An Imperial staircase rises to the east: open string, twisted balusters over vases, moulded handrail. Pairs of painted glass windows light the stairs from a small internal courtyard. The whole of the west side of the first floor is given over to a ceremonial hall of 9 by 3 bays, the bays divided by fluted pilasters. The north wall has paired fluted columns and pilasters, the south wall has Corinthian columns set in front of pilasters. Heavy modillion cornice with leaf-trail decoration and deep coving below a barrel-vaulted roof with eared and shouldered raised panels. The south-east corner of the first floor was used until 1990 as a magistrates court with a complete set of fittings from 1882. Panelled bench and dock, the latter with an internal staircase dropping to a secure room and side entrance on the ground floor. The council chamber has a canopy at the west end and a gallery at the east end. " list.english-heritage.org.uk/resultsingle.aspx?uid=1246969 Full restoration in 2008: archiseek.com/2009/1878-municipal-buildings-great-yarmout... 2012 Google Street View: www.google.com/maps/@52.606173,1.724362,3a,75y,118.9h,100...

"The Rufus Stone A stone known as the "Rufus Stone" (at grid reference SU270124) marks a spot where William II [commonly known as William Rufus or William the Red] supposedly fell . The claim that this is the location of his death appears to date from no earlier than a 17th-century visit by Charles II to the forest. At the time the most popular account of William's death involved the fatal arrow deflecting off a tree, and Charles II appears to have been shown a suitable tree. Letters in The Gentleman's Magazine reported that the tree was cut down and burned during the 18th century. Later in that century the Rufus stone was set up. Originally it was around 5 feet 10 inches tall (1.78 m) with a stone ball on top. King George III visited the stone in 1789, along with his queen, and an inscription was added to the stone to commemorate the visit. It was protected with a cast iron cover in 1841 after repeated vandalism. The inscription on the Rufus Stone reads: Here stood the oak tree, on which an arrow shot by Sir Walter Tyrrell at a stag, glanced and struck King William the Second, surnamed Rufus, on the breast, of which he instantly died, on the second day of August, anno 1100. King William the Second, surnamed Rufus, being slain, as before related, was laid in a cart, belonging to one Purkis and drawn from hence, to Winchester, and buried in the Cathedral Church, of that city." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_II_of_England#The_Rufus_Stone Google Street View, 2011: www.google.com/maps/@50.911403,-1.616883,3a,75y,215.68h,7...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_C._Roper "Daniel Calhoun Roper (April 1, 1867 – April 11, 1943) was a U.S. administrator who served as the 7th United States Secretary of Commerce under President Franklin D. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter_Liggett "Hunter Liggett (March 21, 1857– December 30, 1935) was a lieutenant general of the United States Army. His forty-two years of service spanned the period from the Indian campaigns to trench warfare." "Success in brigade commands in Texas and in the Philippines led to his promotion to major general, and selection as commander of the 41st Division in April 1917. The division served in France as part of the American Expeditionary Force. When his division was disestablished, he took command of I Corps. Under Liggett's leadership, the I Corps participated in the Second Battle of the Marne and in the reduction of the Saint-Mihiel salient. In October 1918, as commander of the US First Army, he directed the final phases of the Meuse-Argonne offensive and the pursuit of German forces until the armistice."

"Tomb of Absalom (Hebrew: יד אבשלום‎, Transl. Yad Avshalom; literally Absalom's Shrine), also called Absalom's Pillar, is an ancient monumental rock-cut tomb with a conical roof located in the Kidron Valley in Jerusalem. The Sunday Oregonian, March 25, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 70 printed a cropped version of this photo with the caption: "Alexandra Stappert is a German girl, late of Bryn Mawr, whom German agents tried to silence when she lectured on the conditions in Germany. She was sent here as a student under a fellowship provided with American money. Dr. Karl Bertling, a German agent, tried to persuade her to stop talking about Germany and then Dr. John A. Mandel of the New York University, wrote a letter to a government official in Berlin, enclosing it in one to Stockholm, reporting her activities. The British censor got the letter. Miss Stappert resigned from Bryn Mawr when relations with Germany were broken off at Washington and has been supporting herself as a governess." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1917-03-25/ed-1/se... Sophie Braslau (1892-1935) was a contralto prominent in United States opera, starting with her debut in New York City's Metropolitan Opera in 1913 when she was just 21 years of age. [1] In her obituary The New York Times wrote, "The singer considered as her greatest triumph an experience during a rehearsal for a concert at Richmond, Va., where she had been sent to substitute for Mme. Louise Homer. After an introduction to the musicians in the empty auditorium, she sang an aria for rehearsal."
"I finished and there came a dead silence," she recalled later, "quickly followed by the strangest sound I had ever heard.  The musicians tapped their music stands with their bows or clapped their hands." In a few seconds it seemed as if pandemonium had let loose, and how happy I was! It was really the finest moment of my life. My mother was there, and it seemed to me that this was her triumph, for the evening concert was a great success and this was the first big joy she had experienced after her many years of devoted supervision."
(Many photographs of Mme. Homer can be seen in the LOC Bain Collection here.) There are currently nine photographs of Sophie Braslau in the LOC Bain Collection from c.1910-1915 here.)

There are a lot of Tokugawas , but I think it is this one: "Prince Tokugawa Iesato (徳川 家達?, August 24, 1863 – June 5, 1940) was the first head of the Tokugawa clan after the overthrow of the Tokugawa bakufu, and a figure in Japanese politics during the Meiji, Taishō and early Shōwa period Japan." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokugawa_Iesato Other pictures at commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Tokugawa_Iesato

Another possibility would be Prince Tokugawa Keikyu, see photograph in the East Oregonian, September 11, 1918, DAILY EVENING EDITION, Image 4 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn88086023/1918-09-11/ed-1/se.... It could be this man IMO. Or it could be Tokugawa Yoshihisa (1884–1922) (according to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokugawa_Yoshinobu-ke), apparently a brother of Keikyu (or the same man?), see photograph in the Rogue River courier, December 03, 1918, DAILY EDITION, Image 1 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn96088180/1918-12-03/ed-1/se.... Both are described as representatives of the Red Cross in Japan. According to www.historyofjapanguide.com/mysterious-japan-017.htm, Prince Keikyu Tokugawa was a son of Yoshinobu (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokugawa_Yoshinobu).

Keikyu and Yoshihisa appear to be the same, since Kikuko, who married Prince Takamatsu (a brother of Emperor Hirohito), is denominated as daughter of Keikyu in www.mocavo.com/The-Japan-Christian-Year-Book-1931/590833/23 and as daughter of Yoshihisa in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kikuko,_Princess_Takamatsu.

indianaillustrators.blogspot.com/2011/01/robert-j-wildhac... Robert J. Wildhack (1881-1940) "Illustrator, poster artist, and comedian Robert J. Wildhack was born on August 27, 1881, in the central Illinois town of Pekin and attended high school in Indianapolis, where he studied under Otto Stark. After graduating from Manual Training High School in 1899, Wildhack worked as an illustrator for the Indianapolis Sentinel before moving to New York City in 1901. " "Shortly before America's entry into World War I, Wildhack joined Charles Dana Gibson, Henry Reuterdahl, and others in the establishment of the Division of Pictorial Publicity of the Committee on Public Information. Between April 1917 and November 1918, the division provided both government and non-government agencies (such as the Red Cross) with hundreds of posters, cards, and cartoons in support of the war effort. The most famous of these works was undoubtedly James Montgomery Flagg’s iconic “Uncle Sam Wants You!” poster."

Another photo of him is in The Sunday Oregonian, July 18, 1915, Section One, Image 16 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1915-07-18/ed-1/se.... According to that, he was colonel. I don't think he was ever a general, even in his own mind. His rank, and even whether his discharge was honorable, was something that fluctuated. By 1889, he had retired as a major (not as a captain as he wanted), and had had 5 court martials and multiple reprieves from 3 presidents. You can tell he was very well-connected in Washington from his autobiography, which is really a diary of his relentless campaign for a brevet (honorary) higher rank, but I'm not sure how that came out. www.youtube.com/watch?v=m9B1MIQfCKg archive.org/details/upsanddownsanar00armegoog

He advanced steadily and was appointed Chief of Engineers for the District of Columbia in 1897. During and after the Spanish-American War, he served as Commander, Department of Engineers, in 'both Cuba and Puerto Rico. In 1906 he was appointed Senior Member of the board for raising the famous battleship Maine, and in 1909 he was promoted to Brigadier General to become Chief of Engineers, Department of the East. In 1916 he was appointed Chief of Engineers, United States Army. His accomplishments were many, including river and harbor improvements in Florida ports and fortification and railroad construction in Cuba. General Black retired a Major General 31 October 1919 and died in Washington, D.C., 24 September 1933." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Murray_Black See earlier photo in Bain stream:

cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19130122.2.188 indicates that Devol was a quartermaster and was in charge of supply services in Panama.

cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19130305.2.56 indicates that his first name was Carroll. See projects.militarytimes.com/citations-medals-awards/recipi... and commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Carroll_A._Devol_headston.... His dates were 1859-1930. He was buried in the Presidio at San Francisco. Widener University has a bio at muse.widener.edu/~widenersoe/alumni.html : "An 1878 civil engineering graduate, went on to a distinguished military career that saw him reach the rank of major general. Following the San Francisco earthquake of 1906, he was placed in charge of distribution of all supplies in the city, and directed the work until civil authorities resumed control. He later served for five years as chief quartermaster – overseeing purchasing and distribution – during the construction of the Panama Canal. He retired before World War I, but returned to serve in the war with honor. A native of Ohio, he died after a protracted illness in 1930 at the age of 71 in Redwood City, Calif. The cause of death was a self-inflicted gunshot to the heart, fired from a .45 Army revolver."

The Music Magazine-musical Courier, Volume 77, August 8, 1918 books.google.com/books?id=HO86AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA3-PA19&am... identifies her as a French singer.

She had made her first New York appearance on January 28, 1917. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E06E0DA173AE4... The enthusiastic review linked above: "That talented singer of French songs who will tour the United States Commencing next Fall. Mme Gabrielle Gills a Grandly Gifted Artist On this page is shown a picture of Mme Gabrielle Gills that glorious French singer of songs whose rarefied art and remarkable personality have interested and inspired audiences wherever this extraordinarily talented woman has appeared during the past few years. It will he remembered that she came to this Country in an official capacity as she was sponsored by the French Government and her mission was to bring to us the highest and finest kind of French vocal art and to set before us the best examples of the French school of song composition. The success of Mme Gills in America was instantaneous and led to keen competition among the managers for the securing of her services after the expiration of her governmental work. Kingsbery Foster was the successful impresario who succeeded in contracting Mme Gills tor a 1918 19 tour of concerts in this country. While patriotic in purpose the Gills appearances last year quickly lost that aspect after the public and the critics had become acquainted with her marvelous art in vocal modulation, diction, and before all things in intelligent and soulful interpretation. It was seen at once that here one had to do with an artist of phenomenal attainments and thereafter ovations extended to her were in the nature of tributes to an artist of genius rather than outbursts of patriotism designed to be complimentary to our French Allies. The chief beauty of Mme Gills art lies in the fact that she is not a vocal virtuosa. That gushing account: "Although she knows all the needs and duties of the singing art and science she does not aim to astonish by the display of throat fireworks and she does not seek sensationalistic effects by confining her repertoire to The Marseillaise, Carillon and similar songs whose chief appeal aside from their intrinsic worth lies of course in their patriotic purport. On the contrary, Mme Gills reaches the hearts of her listeners through a repertoire, a method and an interpretation of the most elevated artistic kind and her main triumphs have been achieved in her renderings of the song classics in the French vocal literature, both ancient modern. It is a study in sublimated vocal art to note how Gills dissects a song into its component parts and makes a perfect presentation of each phase of the composition, musical and literary. In dramatic intensity, in projection, and in soulfulness and in keen sense of proportion and climax no song singer before the public today is more thoroughly effective than Gabrielle Gills. It was no matter for surprise to her American admirers that she was selected in Paris to be the soloist on the occasion of the funeral services of the late Claude Debussy. Mme Gills' tour in the United States will commence next fall and Kingsbury Foster reports that he has had only the success he expected in a magnificently large number of concerts for the French songstress ."

There is very little biographical information on her online after her U.S. appearances around WWI. Several composers dedicated works to her, including Gabriel Fauré. A brief note about her is in a work on Fauré: books.google.com/books?id=pCtURqmcybMC&pg=PA335&d... There are references to her as a teacher at the École normale de musique de Paris in the 30's,40's, and 50's. e.g., fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacques_Herbillon www.legacy.com/obituaries/onlineathens/obituary.aspx?n=wi...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amelita_Galli-Curci "Amelita Galli-Curci (18 November 1882 – 26 November 1963) was an Italian coloratura soprano. She was one of the most popular operatic singers of the early 20th century with her gramophone records selling in large numbers." "Galli-Curci arrived in the United States in the autumn of 1916 as a virtual unknown. Her stay was intended to be brief, but the acclaim she received for her performance as Gilda in Rigoletto in Chicago, Illinois on 18 November 1916 (her 34th birthday) was so wildly enthusiastic that she accepted an offer to remain with the Chicago Opera Company. She was a member of the company until the end of the 1924 season."

I definitely think this is Paul Iogolevitch NYT of July 07, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03E6D6103BEE3AB... mentions his two St George's crosses and other medals in an announcement of an event at which he would be playing his violin.

Several similar views at woottonbridgeiow.org.uk/towill/seaview.php According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seaview,_Isle_of_Wight#Seaview_Pier "In 1877 the Seaview Pier Company was formed to build Seaview a promenading pier, and approval for a 350-yard-long pier was given by Parliament in 1878. The suspension pier was designed by Frank Caws, a Seaview-born engineer/architect then working in Sunderland. The pier was finished in 1881, and was 1000 feet long and 15 feet wide. There were four towers from which the pier deck was suspended. ... The Pier was still in use after World War II, but was destroyed in a storm in late December 1951"

From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryde_Pier#The_Pier_Hotel "In 1930 a bus descending Union Street took the turn into Pier Street too fast and overturned, killing several passengers and pedestrians, and damaging the south front of the Pier Hotel. At the inquest the Pier Hotel was found to be a driving hazard, and instead of being repaired it was ordered to be demolished. By 1931 the Pier Hotel and the entire range of buildings back to the end of St. Thomas's Street had been removed, and Pier Street itself ceased to exist, becoming part of The Esplanade."

However, the Royal Esplanade Hotel, at left, is still functioning as a hotel -- with a coat of paint: from Flickr user Claire Kay in 2009. Current promotional material at www.shearings.com/england/south-coast/hotels/royal-esplan...

See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryde_Pier#Victoria_Pier The trees lining the esplanade have more foliage in the photochrom than in the postcard -- which could mean that the postcard is from a decade earlier than estimated by its owner. Since the photochroms were published in 1905, the underlying photos were clearly taken earlier. I'm not a tree expert, but they look rather young for pollarding.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Needles "The Needles is a row of three distinctive stacks of chalk that rise out of the sea off the western extremity of the Isle of Wight, UK, close to Alum Bay. The Needles Lighthouse stands at the outer, western end of the formation. Built in 1859, it has been automated since 1994. The formation takes its name from a fourth needle-shaped pillar called Lot's Wife that collapsed in a storm in 1764. The remaining rocks are not at all needle-like, but the name has stuck."

"Rusthall and the surrounding area features several sandstone outcrops. One of these formations, located in the Denny Bottom area, close to Rusthall Common, is known as Toad Rock because it resembles a sitting toad. The first known record of the rock's name is in an 1823 guide by J. Clifford, although the rock itself was first popularised in a local guide published in 1810. The fencing around the rock's base was first installed in 1881-2 and has since been renovated in 1993-94." The rock formation is not man-made, as was at first suspected, but was eroded into its current shape by wind action during the Ice Age. The area has been designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rusthall#Toad_Rock "Part of the Tunbridge Wells Sand Formation en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tunbridge_Wells_Sand_Formation recent street view: www.google.com/maps/@51.133875,0.240445,3a,75y,268.72h,78...

It appears that Alfonso XIII of Spain had a lot of ships named after him. This is not a warship and I reckon it is likely one of the two steamships mentioned at books.google.com/books?id=uQY4AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1097&... in Commerce Reports of June 21, 1916. The first sank in 1915 in Santander harbor. The second was bought by the Spanish Compania Transatlantica from the Bermuda-Atlantic Steamship Co. of Toronto. It had been built in 1891 and had an extensive refit and alterations and in June 1916 had just passed her trials for use as a mail and passenger steamer.
that is the ship mentioned earlier today in the wrecksite article. For whatever reason it doesn't display now but they had the same refit history
I can't get that link to open for some reason.

This is the Alfonso XIII that used to the Oceana and had been launched in 1890 as the Scot and which would go on to be the Vasco Nunez de Balboa "She had a clipper stem, two funnels, two masts, twin screw and a speed of 16 knots" says www.theshipslist.com/ships/descriptions/ShipsS.shtml#scot

www.buques.org/Navieras/Trasatlantica/Trasatlantica-1_I.htm has what appears to be a hand-colored version of the same picture. Likely the image was used as promotional material. I've been trying to figure out the location but failing so far.

A NYT story from April, 1916 gives the history and specifications about the ship, then due to to arrive from Cadiz, Spain. It reports that the Spanish Line, aka Compañía Transatlántica Española, planned to dredge Pier 8 on the East River to accommodate her. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9807E5DC1439E2... More likely, she was in the news in February, 1917 when we withdrew our ambassador to Germany, James Gerard, and she was mentioned in connection with his travel plans for the return. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1917-02-16/ed-...

American Line's SS Philadelphia arrived in New York from Liverpool on Feb. 22, 1917, particularly newsworthy in light of heightened tensions with Germany and the break in diplomatic relations: "The American liner Philadelphia, the only passenger vessel flying the American flag to risk a trip across the Atlantic since the German submarine decree became effective, arrived at her pier at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon with 243 passengers on board." More at query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C04E7DE123BEE... The ship's Wikipedia page: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_City_of_Paris_%281888%29

The Choralcelo (not Choracelo) was an electric keyboard musical instrument made by the Choralcelo Company, and apparently there was a studio or showroom "Choralcelo Galleries" in New York at 17 E. 40th Street. This photo may be of that studio. www.amica.org/Live/Publications/Past-Bulletin-Articles/Ch...

This may also be related to: "The New York Electrical Society held its 352d meeting on January 15th [1917] at the Choralcelo Galleries in New York Edward R Knowles lectured on "Dust Its Universality Its Conservatism and Its Elimination," giving some new and valuable data on the subject as well as indicating the part played by electricity in the most effective method of dust separation. After Mr Knowles' address, Guy P Norton spoke on the operative principles of the Choralcelo, the music of which is produced electrically, and a program of the music was rendered. Mr Norton explained how the various values were produced and modified and colored." Scientific American books.google.com/books?id=CbsxAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA97&lp... More in the Electrical Review: " Afterwards Mr Norton explained how the various tone values were created modified and colored, his talk being accompanied by many striking illustrations. The Choralcelo principle is based upon the discovery of a method of controlling the frequency of magnetic impulses and of synchronizing their attack with the natural and fundamental vibrations of sonorous bodies." books.google.com/books?id=TUROAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA106&l... Also, the business announced a series of demonstration recitals in February, 1917 in the Musical Courier. books.google.com/books?id=x-w6AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA6-PA5&...

This is the Ferry Weehawken. The Weehawken was part of the West Shore Railroad (subsidiary of the NY Central Lines) and ran between the West Shore's southern rail terminus at Weehawken and Manhattan terminals at 42nd St and Cortlandt St. Since the ferry is heading south with the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western's 12th Street Pier (near the Hoboken/Jersey City line) in the background it's safe to say it's on the way to Cortlandt St. This photo is actually looking across the route of the (yet to be built) Holland Tunnel. To give perspective, the pier in the background is currently the NJ end of the Holland Tunnel and the photographer would have been standing near the Manhattan end of the Tunnel.
Seuss, Thanks for the better identification of this ferry boat. We will add more information to the record.

As you have identified the man on the right (with crutches) in the LOC Blog article as Congressman William D. Upshaw I will add that nugget here. He was evidently a strong advocate of the the prohibition of alcohol and the temperance movement. Individual States such as Indiana which enacted their own prohibition laws before the Volstead Act en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volstead_Act referred to it as "The Bone Dry Law" so this may be what the bones signify here. These may be prominent prohibition/temperance e campaigners. My feeling is that this was taken during the campaign to repeal the Prohibition Act/18 Amendment in the late 1920s/1930s where the two opposing sides in the argument were commonly referred to as the "Wets" and the "Drys"
National Prohibition Poll lapel badge/pin depicting bone "dry" motif: thumbs1.ebaystatic.com/d/l225/m/mY6QLLVYHutovsJKRi52YeQ.jpg
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/92943860@N00] : I'm convinced we have a bunch of "bone dries" but have so far failed to identify any other than Upshaw.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] I spent ages looking. Unfortunately I don't know enough in depth knowledge of 1920's US politics. There are plenty of references to various key members of the bone drys but relatively few photographs of them on line. I was wondering also whether this might have been the launch of  Upshaw's Presidential bid? I have so far assumed this is Washington DC rather than a local State affair.

swanq and Paul Jackson:  Thanks for your persistence here.  I'm hopeful that something will turn up eventually.  In the mean time, I will add Upshaw's name and connect these folks to the "Dry" movement.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/anne_loc] Thanks Anne. The other gents all look quite distinctive too. Hopefully they have left some other photographic trace somewhere..

Found it! This is a picture of the "bone dry" temperance society with Congressman Upshaw in front of the Capitol. The whole story related to the photo can be found here: thehillishome.com/2015/11/lost-capitol-hill-carrolls-spring/
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/myndrover] well done!

Thanks for your interest and persistence! Somewhere along the line, we got a probable identification for this into our catalog ( www.loc.gov/pictures/item/hec2013004087/) , based on connecting the image to others of Upshaw ( www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=william+upshaw&st=gallery ), and the picture was picked up by the Hill is Home site. I'm glad we're all agreed that the "bone dry" temperance society explains the picture well, and we'll update the description here, so we can all enjoy the satisfaction of another mystery solved!

Congressman William D. Upshaw was the "Dry leader" spreading prohibition. (Also was high ranking member of the Ku Klux Klan, who joined forces with Roy E. Davis and William M. Branham. In the mid 1920's, Upshaw started a campaign slogan, "Bone Dry," using a mechanical bulldog and bone props. Example newspaper article August 17, 1926 in the Akron Beacon Journal. More on Upshaw: seekyethetruth.com/resources-deep-upshaw.aspx More on Davis: seekyethetruth.com/resources-deep-davis.aspx More on Branham: seekyethetruth.com/resources-basics-william_branham.aspx

Upshaw of Georgia, who came to New York yesterday to lecture on 100 per cent. Americanism, announced that he would accept the Democratic nomination for Vice President if it were offered to him at the national convention here in June, and would run as a strictly "bone dry" candidate. A 1931 Harrisburg, PA newspaper account of the car: "MYSTERY CAR TO BE SHOWN HERE A miniature automobile named by its designer and builder, K. L. Morehouse, 30, of Detroit, the "Little Mystery Car," which ' broke the world's small-car record on the Indianapolis Speedway, July 9, 1929, with an average speed per hour of 91.2 miles, will be exhibited here Monday in the radio department of Bowman's department store. Built at a cost of $3000 the car is the first machine to have been transported in an airplane. According to Morehouse, it was taken, fully assembled, in an airplane from Akron to Canton in Ohio. Trained in Detroit at the Ford Motor Company, where he was placed in charge of the experimental department after obtaining an average of 100 per cent, in a four-year tool and dye making course at the Ford plant, Morehouse has built nine miniature automobiles in nine years. Three and a hall years were required to design and build the "Little Mystery Car." It has a fifty-two-inch wheelbase, is twenty-four inches high and thirty-four inches wide; has dual ignition, two carburetors, four-wheel brakes, an electric starter, and weighs 625 pounds. It is capable of traveling 130 miles an hour in fourth speed and develops, 27.2 horsepower at 4000 revolutions. The midget car complete in every detail with four speeds ahead and two in reverse, will arrive in this city on a Pullman from New York City on Monday morning at 11.30. Escorted by city motorcycle, patrolmen, Morehouse will drive it . on a tour of the city and then he will drive into the Bowman store on the elevator and then to the front part of the fifth floor where it will be on display all week. " www.newspapers.com/newspage/57854925/

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/bolobilly] Some of the images near this sequence in the LOC archive show the National Woman's Party Headquarters in Washington DC and this woman collector certainly looks connected to that.

The building over the cop's shoulder is the Commercial National Bank Building. The CNBB was built in 1917 at 14th & G in DC. So, if that's the Colorado Building behind it (1351 G St, also still standing) that would put the photographer/traffic cop at 15th and G outside the Treasury Department. (yes, the streetcar tracks did curve like this there, see this LOC photo: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Streetcars_at_Treasury.jpg) The Federal National Bank sign on the building gives an upper range to a date for this photo. In 1922 FNB merged with American National Bank and became known as Federal American. Federal American began construction on a new building across 14th St (from the SW corner to the SE corner.) That building is not visible here. So - earliest possible is 1917 (CNB Building finished) and latest possible is 1923 (construction of new Federal American building, but given the likelihood that this is suffragist and the 19th Amendment passed in 1920 it's probably not that late.)

She's in a nearby group photo in the collection at LoC at the same spot -- www.loc.gov/pictures/item/hec2013003236/resource/ The women in that picture are wearing striped scarves across their bodies, clearly supporting some cause or movement. And between the two pictures on the street, she's in a room sitting by an older woman with a poster or magazine showing "EQUAL RIGHTS" with a portrait of another woman -- www.loc.gov/pictures/item/hec2013003235/resource/. The woman on the poster may be Lucretia Mott. So this is presumably related to women's suffrage. If the suggested date range is right, this is after women got the vote. The Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which prohibits any United States citizen from being denied the right to vote on the basis of sex, was ratified on August 18, 1920. Perhaps this is related to pressure for an Equal Rights Amendment.

One of the women in the February 14, 1924 picture at www.loc.gov/item/mnwp000198/ is wearing a similar scarf. And everyone in www.loc.gov/resource/mnwp.160026/ is wearing one. It looks as if it represents the National Woman's Party.
The item being held in the adjacent picture is a copy of Equal Rights magazine, which began publication in 1923 and was published by the National Woman's Party.

Since this is likely to be in the Washington DC area, one possibility is the Jefferson District firestation, #5 station in Arlington, VA. fire.arlingtonva.us/locations/fire-station-5-jefferson-di... [watch the cycling images] and arlington392.rssing.com/chan-7530228/all_p2.html both show views of the Jefferson District station. The first is undated with three early engines. The second was taken in the 1950s. The photos show obvious signs of extension and patched brickwork. Could this photo have been taken when that station was being extended by volunteers? From a blog post about the new station opened in 2008: arlingtonfirejournal.blogspot.com/2008/04/new-fire-statio... "The original Company No. 5 was organized on Dec. 17, 1926, when the County Board of Alexandria County - as Arlington was then known - approved the charter of the Jefferson District Volunteer Fire Department. The original company listed seven firefighters on its rolls and operated from a member’s garage at 206 Frazier Avenue - now 23rd Street South - in Aurora Hills. In 1928, the volunteers opened a station at 101 Frazier Ave. (With the adoption of a new street naming scheme, the station was addressed 501 South 23rd St.)." This all seems consistent with this being the station at 101 Frazier Ave (later 501 South 23rd St) during 1927/28 -- but not totally definitive.

Nice detective work swanq. I think you're right, this appears to be the Jefferson District station in Arlington, VA. I searched some newspapers databases to see if I could find a related story but I didn't have any luck. The closest thing I found was an article in the May 18, 1928 issue of the Washington Post which mentioned a celebration for the the opening of the Jefferson fire station. State Senator Frank Ball said "...I would fall far short did I not say that success only followed with the loyal and hearty support of the women of the auxiliary who have worked day and night in the interest of the department."

We have seen her earlier in the Bain photostream, e.g., in May 1916 and Flickr user Blue Ruin 1 believes she was in Japan in December 1916. See SDASM has an album that puts her in China in April 1917
SDASM also has a studio portrait:

Honolulu star-bulletin., December 14, 1916, 2:30 Edition, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1916-12-14/ed-... indicates that she had arrived in Japan and would make her first flight "on Saturday." Honolulu star-bulletin., May 19, 1917, 3:30 Edition, Image 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-05-19/ed-... indicates that she was in Honolulu on her return. So this photo was taken between mid-December 1916 and mid-May 1917.

In late June, 1917, in Chicago and just back from Asia, she talked about her experiences in Japan and China to a Topeka newspaper: "GIRL WHO MADE ORIENT GASP IS TO FLY IN TOPEKA ..."Miss Stinson has just returned to Chicago from a tour of China and Japan, where she won fourteen gold medals and made the Orientals look up to a woman for the first time in history. "The Japanese are really the most polite people in the world," said Miss Stinson, "and the Chinese were just lovely, but I'm certainly glad I'm an American. They make their wives walk ten paces in the rear on all public occasions, and I wouldn't walk behind any man. I want to walk beside him." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016014/1917-06-23/ed-...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rita_Fornia Note transcription error in caption. "Rita Fornia (17 July 1878 – 26 October 1922) was an American opera singer. She began her career in Europe at the beginning of the 20th century singing coloratura soprano roles. Early on in her career her voice darkened and dropped slightly causing her to focus more within the mezzo-soprano repertoire while still singing some soprano roles. She joined the Metropolitan Opera company in 1907 where she performed regularly in mostly supporting roles until her retirement in 1922. She is best remembered today for portraying the role of the Abbess in the original production of Puccini's Suor Angelica in 1918."

New York Naval Militia in early February, 1917, guarding a New York bridge from German sabotage. See
Thanks Art Siegel, we'll update the photo's date range.

In early February, 1917, New York's Governor Charles Whitman mobilized the New York National Guard to guard major infrastructure such as the harbor, bridges and subway system from German sabotage. Alfred Brooks Fry (1860-1933) was the Chief of Staff of the New York Naval Militia at the time, charged with defending New York's bridges. They are shown in surrounding pictures patrolling the bridges. According to a New York Times account on February 5, 1917: "ARMED GUARDS PATROL BRIDGES; Aqueduct System from Croton South Watched by Militiamen. WHOLE GUARD NOT OUT 2,000 Special Officers Protect Subway System;-Armed Tugs in Harbor. Only Part of Guard Called. Close Watch on Bridges. ARMED GUARDS PATROL BRIDGES Orders to Boat Owners. Tug Patrol in East River. Police Censorship. Co-operate with Neutrality Squad. Aviation Field Closed to Visitors. New York yesterday had its first sight of the military patrolling of bridges, water works, aqueducts, and other strategical points since the days of the Spanish war." His New York Times obit, from 1933: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9F0CEED9173AE4... A 1909 biographical sketch of Fry: "Alfred Brooks Fry, marine, mechanical and civil engineer, Advisory Board of Engineers, was born in New York city March 3, 1860. He is a son of Major Thomas William Gardiner Fry, U. S. A., who died of wounds received in Civil War; and a great-grandson of Captain Benjamin Fry, of the Fourth Rhode Island Continental infantry in the Revolution. He was educated at Morse's and other private schools and entered the engineering course at Columbia College in 1877, but gave up the same on going to sea. He worked as a rodman and draftsman from 1877 to 1879; and as a machinist and marine and stationary engineer from 1879 to 1886. He was Assistant Engineer and Chief Engineer under the United States Treasury Department from 1886 to date. He is now on duty as Chief Engineer and Superintendent of United States Public Buildings and of engineering work under the Department of Commerce and Labor and United States Treasury Department, Port of New York. He has served as an engineer in the Naval Militia since its formation in 1892. At present he is Chief of Staff of the Naval Militia, State of New York, with the rank of Lieutenant-Commander. He served in the United States Navy as a Passed Assistant and Acting Chief Engineer in Cuban waters during the Spanish-American War; and has served as a consulting civil, mechanical, and electrical engineer for some of the largest corporations in the Eastern States. [...] He married in 1890 Emma V, daughter of the late Brigadier-General George A. Sheridan, U. S. A., and has one son, Sheridan Brooks Fry, born 1893." files.usgwarchives.net/ny/state/bios/rb1909/fry-alfredb.txt A photo spread on the NYNM, with Brooks' picture, from April, 1917: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1917-04-08/ed-... The celebration of Franklin Roosevelt's 56th birthday in 1938 was used to support his campaign for a fight against infantile paralysis (poliomyelitis), from which he suffered (although he developed it as an adult). Good sport, indeed! Her husband spent the evening at the White House with former aides and campaign staff and made a radio broadcast.

Grade II listed building: "TORQUAY SX8963 COCKINGTON PARK, Cockington 885-1/16/371 Church of St George and St Mary 20/11/52 GV II* Parish church set in landscaped grounds of nearby Cockington Court (qv). Early C13 origins but most of fabric is C14 or C15. Restoration 1882-3 by Hine and Odgers and 1916-20 by Charles Nicholson (architect) and Herbert Read (restoration of screen). Local stone rubble with red sandstone and Beerstone dressings, gable-ended slate roofs. PLAN: Nave and chancel with north and south aisles, the chancel projecting very slightly. C18 or early C19 north porch and C19 vestry on south side of west tower. EXTERIOR: Low tower of 2 stages with crenellated parapet, corner pinnacles, diagonal buttresses and stair turret projecting from middle of north wall. Probably C17 west doorway, 2-centred arch with ovolo surround. North and south aisles with 4-window fronts of 3-light Perpendicular windows with hoodmoulds, another taller version at east end of chancel. Gabled north porch to small round-headed doorway. " www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-390572-church-of-st-g... some more recent photos from flickr users:

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tintern_Abbey "Tintern Abbey (Welsh: Abaty Tyndyrn) was founded by Walter de Clare, Lord of Chepstow, on 9 May 1131. It is situated in the village of Tintern in Monmouthshire, on the Welsh bank of the River Wye which forms the border between Monmouthshire in Wales and Gloucestershire in England. It was only the second Cistercian foundation in Britain, and the first in Wales. It inspired William Wordsworth's poem "Lines written a few miles above Tintern Abbey", Alfred, Lord Tennyson's poem "Tears, Idle Tears", Allen Ginsberg's "Wales Visitation", and more than one painting by J. M. W. Turner. "

"The Great Globe at Swanage is one of the largest stone spheres in the world. The Great Globe is constructed of Portland stone. It weighs about 40 tonnes and is 3 metres (10 ft) in diameter." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Globe

More from the Wikipedia article:
"Constructed in Greenwich in 1887 in Mowlem's stone-yard, it was brought to Swanage by sea. The Globe, which is made of Portland stone, consists of 15 segments, with four stones for each of the lower three courses and three in the top-most course, the segments connected by granite dowels.  It measures 10 feet (3.0 m) in diameter and weighs 40 tons. Its surface is carved in detail and lettered to show the continents, oceans and certain more specific areas of the world."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frieda_Hempel "Frieda Hempel (26 June 1885 – 7 October 1955) was a German soprano singer in operatic and concert work who had an international career in Europe and the United States." "In 1912 she made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York as Marguerite de Valois. She sang regularly in New York thereafter into the 1920s. She was the first to sing the Marschallin in Der Rosenkavalier in New York (for Gatti-Casazza, December 9, 1913) and in Berlin, and she also sang the role in London in 1913. She was in the Met 1913 Un ballo in maschera as Oscar, with Caruso, Emmy Destinn, Margarete Matzenauer and Pasquale Amato, and with them in Boito's Mefistofele; also the 1916 Marriage of Figaro with Matzenauer, Geraldine Farrar and Antonio Scotti. Her La fille du régiment was presented there in 1917. Hempel had a very wide dramatic range, from Rosina or Queen of the Night to Wagner's Eva and Weber's Euryanthe (Metropolitan, 1914 revival)."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinhard_Scheer "Reinhard Scheer (30 September 1863 – 26 November 1928) was an Admiral in the German Kaiserliche Marine. Scheer joined the navy in 1879 as an officer cadet; he progressed through the ranks, commanding cruisers and battleships, as well as major staff positions on land. At the outbreak of World War I, Scheer was the commander of the II Battle Squadron of the High Seas Fleet. He then took command of the III Battle Squadron, which consisted of the newest and most powerful battleships in the navy. In January 1916, he was promoted to Admiral and given control of the High Seas Fleet. Scheer led the German fleet at the Battle of Jutland on 31 May–1 June 1916, one of the largest naval battles in history."
