Arizona Republican article, February 10 1917, uses this photo. WELLESLEY HAS INFALLIBLE METHOD OF PICKING THE "FEMALE FORM DIVINE" How the thoracimeter works. The physical training department of Wellesley College has taken up the whole question of female beauty in a serious way and is rapidly reducing the measurement and classification of the female form divine to an exact science. The latest step forward in the science is the invention by Henry M. Austin of Wellesley of the thoracimeter. The machine in operation is shown above. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020558/1917-02-10/ed-... The article was distributed via some press service of the time and was also published (at least) here: chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1917-02-06/ed-... and chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016014/1917-02-21/ed-...

This photo appeared in the January 19, 1917 Chicago Tribune ( archives.chicagotribune.com/1917/01/19/page/5/article/tho... ) The article gives a fairly good description of how the machine works. The machine is designed as a platform with a standard at the back forming a base for a wide strip of check lined paper before which the beauty contestant stands so that the point of a recording arm may pass directly down the spinal column and an opposite recording arm passes down the midline of the chest in front. When this operation has been completed the strip of paper shows two pencil lines which represent accurately the exact life sized contour of the trunk of the body in cross section side view The Pittsburgh Press of Jan 16 credits Dr. Henry Austin of Wellesley College's Department of Hygiene with its invention. Unfortunately, Wellesley's 1916-1917 catalog lists Henry Austin not as a professor, but as "Superintendent of the College Plant" (head of maintenance). So take the description with a grain of salt. The photo also appears in the January 31 Fort Wayne News and the May 1917 issue of Illustrated World ( books.google.com/books?id=MUQ7AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA359 )

Fascinating. Thanks to both of you for your research. Not sure exactly how the apparatus helps one improve one's appearance.  We'll do our best to add some context to the photo the next time we update the record.

One can also search HathiTrust public domain books and there one finds that this fellow advertised the sale of this device. hdl.handle.net/2027/coo.31924069359473?urlappend=%3Bseq=144 for example - here is the text of such an advertisement: WELLESLEY THORACIMETER Records actual posture or contour lines of the human body; makes life-sized chart and permanent record, enabling Instructors to apply corrective exercises needed for proper development. Used and endorsed by the Department of Hygiene of Wellesley College. For particulars address HENRY H. AUSTIN, WELLESLEY, MASS. It's odd that the one newspaper article talks about the evaluation as though it was for a beauty contestant; in the article "SOME PROBLEMS IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF A DEPARTMENT OF HYGIENE AND PHYSICAL EDUCATION IN A WOMAN'S COLLEGE BY Amy Morris Homans published in 1913 (see hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.b2906135?urlappend=%3Bseq=570 ) it describes use of a different thoracimeter, the "Demeny" thoracimeter, as part of the evaluation process for students applying to a college department. "A full staff of trained assistants makes the drawings of the torso (using the Demeny thoracimeter), the anthropometric measurements and the strength tests. While the collection of this data is desirable for statistical purposes, the College acquires all this information primarily that it may help the individual student."
Thanks for this additional information Michael Neubert.
Oh sure.  I am always interested in seeing how different LC online digitized resources can be knitted together.

This photo ran in The Sunday Oregonian, February 11, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 69 with the caption: "Baseball is to become a world sport. Already it is played in Japan and many other countries abroad. Now Vicomte de la Panouse has written from Monte Carlo to the New York baseball club that after the war he proposes to organize a baseball league of Southern France with four or five teams to play a championship series. He has asked the aid of the New York club in carrying out the idea. It is likely a number of American players will be sent to France, if they choose to go, for the purpose of helping out the plan."

racineshistoire.free.fr/LGN/PDF/La-Panouse.pdf is a family tree for the La Panouse family. According to that, in 1917, Marie-Melchior Eugène de La Panouse would have been Comte. I don't see an obvious candidate vicomte here.

NYT of Jan 05, 1917. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9803E2D71438EE32A... reports on the first of the trials associated with Margaret Sanger's first birth control clinic began. At issue was the New York law prohibiting dissemination of information on the subject of birth control. The first trial was for Mrs. Ethel Byrne, Sanger's sister. The trial was in Brooklyn. Also on trial would be Sanger herself (later in January) and Fania Mindell (later). See Mindell at There was lots of news coverage during January and February of 1917, for example, NYT of Jan 30, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F00EEDA173AE433A... of Feb 3, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A01E7DD1538EE32A...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sophie_Braslau "Sophie Braslau (August 16, 1892 – December 22, 1935) was a contralto prominent in United States opera, starting with her debut in New York City's Metropolitan Opera in 1913 when she was just 21 years of age."
Hear how she sounded in 1917, singing 'The Sweetest Story Ever Told' - youtu.be/BjTXeUM502E

In her obituary The New York Times wrote, "The singer considered as her greatest triumph an experience during a rehearsal for a concert at Richmond, Va., where she had been sent to substitute for Mme. Louise Homer. After an introduction to the musicians in the empty auditorium, she sang an aria for rehearsal."
"I finished and there came a dead silence," she recalled later, "quickly followed by the strangest sound I had ever heard.  The musicians tapped their music stands with their bows or clapped their hands." In a few seconds it seemed as if pandemonium had let loose, and how happy I was! It was really the finest moment of my life. My mother was there, and it seemed to me that this was her triumph, for the evening concert was a great success and this was the first big joy she had experienced after her many years of devoted supervision."
(Many photographs of Mme. Homer can be seen in the LOC Bain Collection here.) There are currently nine photographs of Sophie Braslau in the LOC Bain Collection from c.1910-1915 here.)

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horace_Plunkett "Sir Horace Curzon Plunkett, KCVO, PC, DL, JP, FRS (24 October 1854 – 26 March 1932), was an Anglo-Irish agricultural reformer, pioneer of agricultural cooperatives, Unionist MP, Irish Senator and author." "During the First World War the cooperatives were severely hit as farmers avoided their high standards, supplying inferior produce directly to Great Britain, where food shortages led to a boom period for Irish agriculture. Much of Plunkett's time was spent as an unofficial envoy between Britain and the United States, and after the Easter Rising of 1916 he spent his energy seeking clemency for its leaders."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_Garden "Mary Garden (20 February 1874 – 3 January 1967), was a Scottish-American operatic soprano with a substantial career in France and America in the first third of the 20th century. She spent the latter part of her childhood and youth in the United States and eventually became an American citizen, although she lived in France for many years and eventually retired to Scotland, where she died."
See also www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/15819503636/

She was reported arriving in New York on the liner Baltic from Liverpool, on the date on this negative and sticker, 12/19/14. She had announced in early December that she was returning for Christmas, but would go right back to attend to her hospital for blind soldiers in France. This and 2 surrounding negatives were renumbered from the 3333 series (containing images from December, 1914) to the 4116 series. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9506E4DE1438E6... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E04E0DD103EE7... query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=980CE5DF1438E6...

A similar International News Service photo clearly taken at the same time, ran in the East Oregonian (Pendleton, Umatilla Co., Or.) on December 26, 1914 with the caption: "MARY GARDEN BACK FROM WAR ZONE. Miss Garden as she appeared upon her arrival on the S. S. Baltic, Saturday. December 19. NEW YORK. Dec. 26. Mary Garden is back in New York, but not to sing. Distressed by scenes of carnage in northern France, the diva, who has been doing hospital work In the war zone, came back to visit her mother, eat Christmas dinner at home and raise funds for her hospital. Besides the hospital which Miss Garden and some of her friends are maintaining from private funds, she has turned her home In Versailles into a home for Belgian refugees. "I have come over to make a personal appeal for funds to keep up the home," she said. "Thus far two other ladies and myself have supported it from our private funds, but the class are so many and the need so great that unless we have help I do not know what will happen to the home." oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn88086023/1914-12-26/ed-1/se... Similar story with photo in The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) December 27, 1914. oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1914-12-27/ed-1/se...
Thanks, all, for the information and for finding the likely context for the photo. We'll add to the description.

I think that Rev. John van Schaick, Jr is clearly another man, there are many photos of him, see e.g. The Sunday Oregonian. (Portland, Ore.) 1881-current, January 31, 1915, SECTION FIVE, Image 65 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83045782/1915-01-31/ed-1/se.... My guess is that this is the German vice consul in San Francisco von Schaick. According to The Bourbon news., January 26, 1917, Page 3, col 1, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86069873/1917-01-26/ed-..., he was sentenced for violation of American neutrality. His name is given there as "E. H. von Schaick" (the line with his name is by mistake at the top of the column). In other articles, he is named Baron von Schaick, see e.g. fultonhistory.com/Newspapers%2023/Jamestown%20NY%20Evenin... col. 4, "TESTIFY TO GERMAN PLOTS". In newspaperarchive.com/us/nevada/reno/reno-evening-gazette/..., he is Eckhardt T. von Schaick.
I think this is not the Rev. van Schaick referred to in swanq's post, who was a smaller and more wiry fellow (follow the links below this earlier Bain photo for more photos):

I also think this isn't the German von Schaick in the news in 1917, but probably instead a member of the old and prominent New York van Schaick family.  The date on the negative is 12/14/14, and this and two nearby negatives were renumbered from a series with 1914 photos in it.

I think the man is John Brodhead Van Schaick (1865-1918), Harvard Law class of 1888-89. In a lengthy obituary (with photo) from St. Mark's School, it is recounted that he sailed for Europe on 12/12/14 to join the Ambulance Corps. His wife served as a Red Cross nurse in France. Despite his advanced age, he returned to Europe in 1918 after the U.S. entered the war, and died in Germany that year. books.google.com/books?id=KZ8iAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA247&l... His wife is identified as Lotta C. J. Van Schaick (1875 - 1961), on findagrave: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=92671946 New York Times death notice says J.B. was the son of the late Jenkins and Maria C. van S., and that his widow was Lotta Carli Johnston van S. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=940CE7DB1E39E1...
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] : I think you have it.  The photo  in the St. Marks obituary looks a much better match.

John Van Schaick and his wife, Lotta, pictured in the first photo, are relatives of my husband.  Her full name is Lotta Carll Johnston and she was Van Schaick's second wife.  The Rev. Van Schaick, to my knowledge, is no relation.  They had a son, also named John Brodhead Van Schaick, who was born in 1917 and  who, after joining the Army after graduating from M.I.T. with an engineering degree, was killed in World War II at Sessenheim, France, in an early morning battle with the Germans.  John Brodhead Van Schaick came from an old New York Dutch family that traced its history back to the late 17th - early 18th century.  His father, Jenkins Van Schaick founded the stock brokerage firm, Van Schaick & Co., and was instrumental in getting the Brooklyn Bridge built.  John Brodhead Van Schaick took the firm over when his father died in 1899.  Lotta Van Schaick passed away in 1961.

Judith Bernays Heller (1885 - 1977) www.geni.com/people/Judith-Heller/6000000004537926434 In 1917, Elie Nadelman wanted to marry her, but her father made her break off the engagement (according to "Anonymous in Their Own Names: Doris E. Fleischman, Ruth Hale, and Jane Grant" by Susan Henry, p. 55 books.google.com/books?id=A52L6cD9wYcC&pg=PA55&lp... Judith Bernays was a sister of Edward Bernays (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Bernays) and a daughter of Sigmund Freud's sister Anna. On this photo, she is obviously in the studio of Nadelman. Elie Nadelman: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/15870608519/
LOC apparently has Judith Bernays Heller's papers: lccn.loc.gov/mm2002084855

A casting of the horse in the background was apparently owned by Helena Rubenstein, and a photograph of her with it appears in a book with the caption: "Although small, Madame presents a statuesque appearance as she stands by one of Elie Nadelman’s masterpieces, a plaster horse that synthesizes the sculptor’s taste for classical Greek sculpture and American folk art weathervanes." www.pointedleafpress.com/over-the-top A more detailed history of "Horse", which adds that Madame Rubenstein bought out the complete 1911 exhibition of Nadelman's work, including Horse. artsearch.nga.gov.au/Detail.cfm?IRN=75972

The Bernays-Nadelman engagement was announced in the New York Times on January 6, 1917, with a wedding to occur at the end of February. It identifies her as a 1907 Barnard graduate and a niece of Sigmund Freud. It reports that she and Nadelman bonded over mutual interest in Freud's theories two years earlier. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9A01E7D61438EE... see also
See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/15434380654/

Would this be for the Electoral College? Each state's votes are sent to the President of the Senate (i.e. the VP of the United States).

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_R._Marshall "Thomas Riley Marshall (March 14, 1854 – June 1, 1925) was an American Democratic politician who served as the 28th Vice President of the United States (1913–1921) under Woodrow Wilson." "An ideological rift developed between the two men during their first term, leading Wilson to limit Marshall's influence in the administration, and his brand of humor caused Wilson to move Marshall's office away from the White House. " Another photo clearly taken on the same occasion, with the same glove on the ground, was published in the New-York Tribune, 28 Jan. 1917, Graphic Section Two, Image 53 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-01-28/ed-... Caption reads "The official count of the vote in California, which re-elected President Wilson, was delivered to the United States Senate by Francis I Heney. Vice-President Marshall received it and expressed his thanks." So, yes, this is part of the electoral college process after the November 1916 election.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/kaiban] 
As a large format photographer, I assume the glove was there for the photographer to pre-focus on. It would save time.

Then when the group assembled all they had to do was have the most important people stand by the glove.

What is also odd is all the wasted space below and above the group. 

I am wondering if the photographer composed the photograph to fit a preconceived layout where the feet (and legs ?) would be cropped off. The layout may have used text over the pillars in the background.

It would be interesting if someone could find an example where the photograph was used.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Thanks for nailing this down. Good historical work.
swanq: thank you for finding more information on Thomas Marshall as well as what was going on.  We'll add it to the record.
Same location, same glove. Perhaps it belongs to the photographer.

More on Francis J. Heney, to the left of Marshall: "Francis Joseph Heney (March 17, 1859 Lima, New York – October 31, 1937 Santa Monica, California) was a lawyer, judge, and politician." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_J._Heney Marshall in another Bain photo:

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/terrythomasatlanta]  I think you are correct that the glove is a focus mark for the subjects.  I doubt that it is connected with a particular composition to be assembled later.  While we've seen a lot of examples of those, it doesn't seem that the photographer (who works for a news service) is in on it, but that the layout people at individual papers did that work.
It's also clear in many pictures that the photographer knew the background would be cut out, so that no care needed to be taken to have an appropriate background.

Possibly en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_W._Lawson_(businessman) "Thomas William Lawson (February 26, 1857 – February 8, 1925) was an American businessman and author. A highly controversial Boston stock promoter, he is known for both his efforts to promote reforms in the stock markets and the fortune he amassed for himself through highly dubious stock manipulations."
He was in the news around the turn of the year from 1916 to 1917. See The Chicago Day Book., December 28, 1916, LAST EDITION, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045487/1916-12-28/ed-...
swanq: thanks for finding more information on Thomas Lawson.  We'll add it to the record.

Lawson's allegations that market insiders knew of and profited from an early leak of Wilson peace overtures around Christmas, 1916 were central to the House Rules Committee leak investigation in January. Here's what an editorial in the El Paso (TX) Herald said about Lawson in January, 1917: "Lawson Shoots His Wad" After all, Thomas W. Lawson, in the "leak" investigation conducted by the house rules committee, gave about the testimony expected of him, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. He was bombastic and vituperative, but short on facts and figures. He could not be pinned down to give the names of those who, he claimed, gave out the advance information on the president's peace note which is alleged to have resulted in a Wall Street clean-up. He could not, or did not, name a single person who profited by such alleged information, save himself. Claiming to have enough information to create a national sensation, he fought shy of giving any of it under the most insistent prompting. Having gone to Washington with the announcement that he would aid the investigation, he aided it not at all. , The country will believe that Mr. Lawson, in fact, told about all he knew, which was nothing whatever but the ordinary Wall Street gossip of every day circulation. Having no evidence which would justify him in making charges against any individual, he was shrewd enough to restrain his love of playing to the galleries and refrain from naming anyone." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88084272/1917-01-09/ed-...
This picture ran in The Daily Ardmoreite (Ardmore, OK), January 08, 1917. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042303/1917-01-08/ed-...

Calling themselves the " Silent Sentinels," a rotating cluster of women stood at the White House gates for months. They carried signs intended to challenge and embarrass Wilson."

The picketing campaign began on January 10, 1917. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9806E2D61438EE... The picketing was done by 12 "silent sentinels" daily, 6 at each of the two gates to the semi-circular driveway. See myinwood.net/libbey-castle/ The castle (demolished in the 1930s) is seen with and without an "e." The location seems to be most often called "Washington Heights" with "Fort Washington Park" nearby. Note, there should not be a comma between Washington and Heights.

Like Libbey Castle, this mansion, Tryon Hall, was in Washington Heights. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C.K.G._Billings for info on Cornelius Kingsley Garrison Billings and Tryon Hall which includes, "By 1916 Billings had tired of this location, and sold the whole operation to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. for $35,000 per acre. Rockefeller intended to tear down Tryon Hall initially and give the land to the city for a new park. Inwood and Washington Heights was in need of a park in the neighborhood, Architects protested destruction of the house and the city turned down the offer of a new park. It was rented out. Tryon Hall burned in a spectacular fire in 1926, and the city finally accepted Rockefeller’s gift of the new 67-acre (27 ha) Fort Tryon Park, which opened in 1935. All that remains today of the estate is the old gatehouse near the park entrance and its famous driveway."
Some more photos: www.forttryonparktrust.org/image_album.html?id=6

Marian Walker was a graduate of the School of Nutrition at Columbia's Teachers' College and ran the 25 cents/day challenge. She oversaw the purchase of supplies and menu preparation. NYT identifies Mary McCormick simply as an assistant to Mary S. Rose (Mary Swartz Rose, Ph.D taught Nutrition at Teachers College from 1909-1941) who tabulated the daily nutritional values of the meals. She was really far more interesting and the brief bio included with her collected papers is well worth reading. She graduated from Cornell in 1906 and earned an MA from Columbia in 1908. From 1911 to 1918 she was an instructor in "Household Arts and Nutrition" at Columbia Teachers College. Lt. George L. Sullivan represented the Commissioner at the test. There is an unnamed fourth person in the photograph - the cook who actually does all the work. An article in the Columbia Daily Spectator refers to "Oscar, the negro chef who carries out Miss Walker's instructions." A Jan. 17 NYT article however, refers to "Hannibal V. Parsons, the colored chef. " A week later the NYT reported that Hannibal Vesszey Parsons (who had studied to be a Baptist minister and been a chef at Wells College) had been offered $1,800/yr to cook at a well known restaurant, but had promised to finish the Diet Squad experiment first.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00]: Your link to McCormick's bio got corrupted somehow. www.strose.edu/download.aspx?libitemid=15683&file=Mar... works for me.
Thanks Seuss and swank, this is a very interesting story. We'll add some more information to the catalog record.

Three of these gentlemen were mentioned as members of a Japanese commission that visited the U. S in October 1917 offering support against Germany in WWI. NYT of Oct 30, 1917 [query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C05EEDD113AE433A...] and of Oct 31, 1917 [query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0DE5DC113AE433A...]. An earlier article, from August 18, 1917, describes them as legislators and the Oct 30 article says the commission represents all four political parties. Names obviously matching include Kotaro Mochisuki (also spelt Mochizuki and Machizuka), Toshio Shimada and Masatsugu Yamane. The group was headed by Tokiochi Masao (Massao) which could be Masawa.

Interesting story: Orihime (織姫 Weaving Princess?), daughter of the Tentei (天帝 Sky King, or the universe itself?), wove beautiful clothes by the bank of the Amanogawa (天の川 Milky Way, lit. "heavenly river"?). Her father loved the cloth that she wove and so she worked very hard every day to weave it. However, Orihime was sad that because of her hard work she could never meet and fall in love with anyone. Concerned about his daughter, Tentei arranged for her to meet Hikoboshi (彦星 Cow Herder Star?) (also referred to as Kengyuu (牽牛?)) who lived and worked on the other side of the Amanogawa. When the two met, they fell instantly in love with each other and married shortly thereafter. However, once married, Orihime no longer would weave cloth for Tentei and Hikoboshi allowed his cows to stray all over Heaven. In anger, Tentei separated the two lovers across the Amanogawa and forbade them to meet. Orihime became despondent at the loss of her husband and asked her father to let them meet again. Tentei was moved by his daughter’s tears and allowed the two to meet on the 7th day of the 7th month if she worked hard and finished her weaving. The first time they tried to meet, however, they found that they could not cross the river because there was no bridge. Orihime cried so much that a flock of magpies came and promised to make a bridge with their wings so that she could cross the river. It is said that if it rains on Tanabata, the magpies cannot come and the two lovers must wait until another year to meet. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanabata

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_festivals Matsuri (祭?) is the Japanese word for a festival or holiday. There is a Chinese version of the legend and festival too. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qixi_Festival

from Wikipedia: "Tanabata (七夕 Date: July 7 / August 5–8 (Sendai) Other Names: The Star Festival Information: It originated from a Chinese folk legend concerning two stars-the Weaver Star (Vega) and the Cowherd Star (Altair)-who were said to be lovers who could meet only once a year on the 7th night of the 7th month provided it didn't rain and flood the Milky Way. It was named Tanabata after a weaving maiden from a Japanese legend, named Orihime who was believed to make clothes for the gods. People often write wishes and romantic aspirations on long, narrow strips of coloured paper and hang them on bamboo branches along with other small ornaments." Quite a few Flickr pictures of this festival: www.flickr.com/search?sort=relevance&text=tokyo%20tan...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Henderson "Arthur Henderson PC (13 September 1863 – 20 October 1935) was a British iron moulder and Labour politician. He was the first Labour cabinet minister, the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize Laureate and served three terms as the Leader of the Labour Party. " "In 1914, the First World War broke out, and the then-Labour leader, Ramsay MacDonald, resigned in protest. Henderson was elected to replace him, and in 1915, following Prime Minister H. H. Asquith's decision to create a coalition government, became the first member of the Labour Party to become a member of the Cabinet, as President of the Board of Education. In 1916, David Lloyd George forced Asquith to resign and replaced him as Prime Minister. Henderson became a member of the small War Cabinet with the job of Minister without Portfolio. "

The date on sticker is 1/5/17, but this photo was in The Sunday Oregonian, July 04, 1915, SECTION FIVE, Image 59 already. The caption was: " Arthur Henderson is the new labor member of the British Cabinet. He is a native of Glasgow. He was apprenticed to a moulder at Newcastle. Later he held official positions In the government of that city and finally was sent to Parliament. He is secretary of the Labor party. He was a member of the Railway Royal Commission." The same (or a very similar) photo is in The North Platte semi-weekly tribune., January 05, 1917, Image 6, "LABOR'S MAN IN WAR CABINET"

See Mrs Moschzisker is likely Anne as at www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=108681288. According to www.poles.org/db/m_names/Moschzisker_R/Moschzisker_R.html she was the former Anne Macbeth. Thanks swanq for the names of these people. I noticed that the sash Ms. Moschzisker is wearing says "2nd Made In America". I did some searches based on that and found that the Emergency Aid In Pennsylvania organizations held their 2nd Made In America Bazaar in December of 1916. On December 17th there was a Polish Meeting where Mr. Paderewski gave a speech in Polish and in English describing the conditions in his country. The Moschzisker's were listed as dinner guests for that evening. There is an article from the Philadelphia Evening Ledger in the Library's Chronicling America at chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045211/1916-12-16/ed-....

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Milner,_1st_Viscount_Milner "Alfred Milner, 1st Viscount Milner KG GCB GCMG PC (23 March 1854 – 13 May 1925) was a British statesman and colonial administrator who played an influential leadership role in the formulation of foreign and domestic policy between the mid-1890s and early 1920s." "In January 1917 Milner led the British delegation (with Henry Wilson as chief military representative and including a banker and two munitions experts) on the mission to Russia. There were 50 delegates in total including French (led by de Castelnau) and Italians. The object of the mission, stressed at the second Chantilly Conference in December 1916, was to keep the Russians holding down at least the forces now opposite them, to boost Russian morale and see what equipment they needed with a view to coordinating attacks. The official report in March said that even if the Tsar was toppled—which in fact happened a few weeks later—Russia would remain in the war and that they would solve their “administrative chaos”."

A cropped version of this photo was used in The Sunday Oregonian, January 14, 1917, SECTION FIVE, Image 65 with the caption: "Lord Milner is a member of Lloyd George's Cabinet. He has been identified with public life in Great Britain for many years."
Thanks swanq and B-59, we'll add his full name to the catalog record and adjust the date range.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Balfour "Arthur James Balfour, 1st Earl of Balfour, KG, OM, PC, DL (UK /ˈbælfə/;[1] 25 July 1848 – 19 March 1930) was a British Conservative politician who was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from July 1902 to December 1905." "When Asquith's government collapsed in December 1916, Balfour, who seemed a potential successor to the premiership, became Foreign Secretary in Lloyd George's new administration, but not in the small War Cabinet, and was frequently left out of inner workings of government. Balfour's service as Foreign Secretary was notable for the Balfour Declaration of 1917, a letter to Lord Rothschild promising the Jews a "national home" in Palestine, then part of the Ottoman Empire."

Emma Lucy Gates Bowen (1882-1951) was a popular operatic soprano in the early 20th Century. She was originally from Utah and was a granddaughter of Brigham Young. In July 1916 (maybe 6-7 months before this photo?) she married Utah attorney and businessman Albert E. Bowen (who went on to become a member of the LDS Quorum of 12 - a very big deal) though she continued to perform professionally as "Miss Lucy Bates." She is using an Underwood No. 4 typewriter. In the full size .tiff the letterhead in the typewriter is identifiable as that of the Latter Day Saints University. Lucy's brother and business partner B. Cecil Gates was the head of the music department at that school.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Square_Players "The Washington Square Players was a New York theatrical production company founded in 1914. Its debut production in 1915 was a collection of one-act plays, some of which had been written for the event. In 1916 the troupe started presenting full-length plays, among which were Shaw's Mrs Warren's Profession and translations of Chekhov's The Seagull and Ibsen's Ghosts. That same year it moved into the Comedy Theatre, where it subsequently performed Eugene O'Neill's one-act play In the Zone in 1917. In 1918 the company produced Elmer Rice's The Home of the Free. In the same year, the Washington Square Players disbanded, but its work served as the roots for the foundation of the Theatre Guild in 1919." See also rickontheater.blogspot.com/2012/06/washington-square-play...

A candidate for Mrs. John Garrett is the former Alice Warder, shown at bigoldhouses.blogspot.com/2014/06/high-art-and-deep-pocke... as elegant, fashion-conscious, and wealthy -- possibly to the right of the flags in a fur coat and very elegant shoes. According to www.josephsheppard.com/Book/early.htm "Mrs. Garrett lived in Paris from 1914 through 1917 while her husband John Work Garrett' was Special Agent of the State Department in charge of Civilian Prisoners of War, and returned to Paris in 1934 after Mr. Garrett completed his post as Ambassador to Italy and retired from the diplomatic corps." Since the photo is by the same photographer, Wyndham, as nearby photos of French soldiers, perhaps this fête was in Paris.

NYT of Dec 14, 1915 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9902EFDD1E38E633A... indicates that Lieutenant Commander William Randall Sayles and his wife were in Paris at the time, where he was Naval Attaché at the American Embassy. The photo on her findagrave page [www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=81148768] is compatible with the leftmost woman, below the corresponding name -- but not a certain match.

And the former Olive W. Thompson was Mrs Perry Tiffany. Her husband's findagrave biography [www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=88043028] says, "Mr. and Mrs. Tiffany spent the war years in France doing work for the French Red Cross and the British canteens long before the United States joins the Allies. "

From NYT of Dec 5, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C07E6D91F3FE233A... "Bazaar Directed by Mrs. Joseph A. Blake Raises a Large Fund." It was held in the Salle de Fetes at the Passy Mairie. From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passy "Passy is an area of Paris, France, located in the 16th arrondissement, on the Right Bank. It is traditionally home to many of the city's wealthiest residents." NYT of Dec 1, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C04EEDA1F3FE233A... adds the names of Mrs. John Garrett and Miss Sharp to the Americans involved. This is likely the event and location for this picture.
Margaret Sharp, the daughter of the American Ambassador, is also depicted in this photo: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/14333009640/

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poilu "Poilu (/ˈpwɑːluː/; French: [pwaly]) is an informal term for a French World War I infantryman, meaning, literally, hairy one. The term came into popular usage in France during the era of Napoleon and his massive citizen armies, though the term grognard (grumbler) was also common. It is still widely used as a term of endearment for the French infantry of World War I. "

According to www.readperiodicals.com/201003/1983220541.html, Wilfrid Douthitt aka Louis Graveure was a singer as well. "He married Eleanor Painter in 1916. She had trained in Berlin, and was considered a very fine operatic soprano. She made her debut as Madama Butterfly in 1912 at Deutsche Oper and continued singing repertory in that Fach both in the U.S. and Europe during her married life. From 1920, Louis Graveure, too, sang recitals and operatic performances in Berlin. Eleanor divorced Louis in 1930, subsequently marrying a wealthy businessman."

USS Caesar (AC-16) (formerly the Merchant Ship Kingtor) Caesar left NYC December 19, 1916 bound for Alexandria with a cargo of Red Cross relief supplies for Syrian (actually Assyrian) refugees.

Lt. Commander John Matt Enochs (1878-1932) was the captain of the USS Caesar (AC-16). Cleveland Hoadley Dodge (note H, not K) founded the American Committee for Armenian and Syrian Relief in 1915 Henry Morgenthau was ambassador to the Ottoman Empire from 1913 to 1916 and was the most prominent American to speak out against the Armenian Genocide. "Wife" had a name. Josephine Sykes Morgenthau. The Caesar, a converted collier, was loaded with 200,000 tons of food and other relief supplies for "Syrian" refugees (actually "Assyrian".) The ship sailed from NY 19 Dec 1916 for Beirut with intermediate stops at Gibraltar and Alexandria. This was known as "The Christmas Ship"

James Leslie (Les) Darcy was an Australian boxer. from www.secondsout.com/columns/paul-upham/les-darcy-tribute-u... As the issue of conscription arose during the First World War, Darcy became a pawn in a tug of war between the Australian government and his mother. Under the age of 21, which disqualified him from automatic acceptance into the armed forces, twice Darcy attempted to enlist, but his mother Margaret refused to give her written consent. As more Australians lost their lives in World War I, Darcy continued his boxing career, but came under greater scrutiny from his critics. While conscription was still optional, the Australian government prevented Darcy from legally leaving the country to travel to fight in America. On 19 February 1916, Darcy knocked out Harold Hardwick in seven rounds to win the Australian heavyweight title. His final fight in Australia was on 30 September 1916, when he knocked out George Chip in nine rounds. Two days before his 21st birthday on 29 October 1916, Darcy stowed away on an ocean steamer bound for the USA and arrived in New York six weeks later. He was publicly portrayed as a coward by his critics in both Australia and America. After Darcy took the oath of allegiance to become an American citizen and joined the American Air Force, promoters arranged his first foreign fight in the USA to be held on 7 May 1917. Whilst training for his American debut, Darcy collapsed on 27 April 1917. He was admitted to hospital with septicaemia and endocarditis. It was suggested his blood poisoning had come from a fight a year earlier where he had lost two teeth. His tonsils were removed but he developed pneumonia and died on 24 May 1917. This photo is likely from his arrival in NYC in mid-December

This is Swedish runner John Adolf Fredrik Zander (1890-1967). He competed in the 1912 and 1920 Olympics in the 1500m and 3000m distance running events. He won a silver medal in the 3000m in 1912, and a bronze in the 3000m in 1920.
The sticker on the negative reads 12/30/16. Perhaps taken in Stockholm in October, 1916. See note under
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Zander

This is Swedish runner Anatole Bolin (Jakob Pehr Anatole Dedekind Bolin) (1893-1983). He held the world record in the 1000 yard event 1918-1922. He competed in the 400m and the 800m events of the 1920 Olympics but did not medal. The photo was likely taken in Stockholm Stadium in 1917 when Bolin set a Swedish record in the 1000m and 400m events, August 19-20, 1917. The neutral Scandinavian nations held an annual track and field meet as usual throughout the war, and this may be the 1917 meet where the photo was taken. All of the flags in the photo appear to be of Scandinavian nations.

The 1916 Olympics were cancelled due to WWI, but the US AAU sent a team to compete with the best of the Scandinavians in a series of five meets in October, 1916, four in Sweden (the first meet in Stockholm, held October 14-15) and one in Norway--the US delegation did very well, winning on points. The US AAU invited Bolin and fellow countryman John Zander to compete in the US in the spring of 1917, but due to the hazards of wartime ocean travel, the Swedish athletic governing authority declined.

Gaston Ernest Liébert was born in Paris in 1866. He entered the Naval College in 1884 and served in the Navy for seven years. In 1893, he entered the diplomatic corps and was sent to the Far East in 1898. He served as French Vice-Consul to Pakhoi and Tunghing (China), 1899-1901; envoy for a special mission to the French Legation in Peking following the Boxer Rebellion, 1901-1902; French Consul to Hong Kong, 1903-1916; and Consul-General in New York, 1916. Died in 1929.

Presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connaught_Tunnel_(British_Columbia) "The Connaught Tunnel is a railway tunnel under the Selkirk Mountains in southeastern British Columbia, Canada, near the city of Revelstoke. The 5.022-mile (8.082 km) tunnel carries the Canadian Pacific Railway main line under Mount Macdonald and replaced the railway's previous routing over Rogers Pass, which had been struck by several deadly avalanches since its completion in 1885. Announced in February 1913, the contract was awarded on July 1, 1913, ... The tunnel was completed before the original deadline, with operation beginning December 16, 1916. "
www.avenidagalleries.com/art/max-jacquiard/60873/ is a painting showing the mountain behind.

The Sunday Oregonian, December 24, 1916, SECTION FIVE, Image 47 printed this photo with the caption: "The Connaught tunnel, the longest continuous double-track mountain railway tunnel on this hemisphere, has just been completed. Three years and a half were allotted to the construction, and it was finished three weeks ahead of time, its method or construction was unusual. A small tunnel was first driven, through which were carried the working pipes. This allowed continuous work at all points. The tunnel, which runs under Mount Macdonald in the Selkirks, is five miles long, and it reduces the mileage of the Canadian Pacific by four miles. The cost was $6,500,000."

This is probably the Committee on Public Information (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Committee_on_Public_Information); one of the CPI leaders was the "father of public relations," Edward Bernays -- if this speculation is correct, he would be the second from the right, with the mustache. (Photos in Google image search; bio at Wikipedia.) He is known character at LC, where his paper lie. Several selections were scanned for the "Prosperity and Thrift" (Calvin Coolidge Era) American Memory collection: type in Bernays on this search page: memory.loc.gov/ammem/coolquery.html.

Nicholas Murray Butler. Longtime president of Columbia University and Republican activist. His brief opinions were constantly being sought to round out articles. Today he'd be a Cable TV commentator. In late 1916 Woodrow Wilson's (a Democrat) re-election was largely (by Republicans looking for a scapegoat) laid to the failure of Charles Evans Hughes' failure to carry California. While Butler was the only national Republican to campaign in California for Hughes, it was suggested that his support was lukewarm and purposely weak and sent the wrong message. Butler was named as one of the party establishment behind the decision to pull resources from California. He responded in the negative. It was a (very minor) kerfuffle in the papers in late 1916.
Thanks Seuss, we'll add his full name to the catalog record.

In 1912, he was ambassaor to the United States. See www.ciaowashington.com/national-columbus-memorial-centenn... "The celebration marked the 100th year since the unveiling of the Columbus Memorial. According to the June 9, 1912 edition of The Washington Herald, it was then Italian Ambassador Marquis Cusani Confalonieri who at the end of his remarks was “handed a rope connected with the drapings around the statue . . .The Ambassador gave the rope a vigorous pull. The two gigantic American flags were loosened from the monument floating majestically in the breeze from from the cable extending over the site, revealing in all its ravishing beauty the statue of Columbus.” For another portrait, see photograph of drawing at the Smithsonian: collections.si.edu/search/results.htm?q=record_ID:siris_j...

According to www.ambtokyo.esteri.it/Ambasciata_Tokyo/Menu/I_rapporti_b..., his full name was Luigi Girolamo Cusani Confalonieri, and he was ambassador to Japan from April 9, 1917 until February 17, 1920. (But it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raniero_Paulucci_di_Calboli ("Collegamenti esterni", at the bottom) says that this mandate ended in 1919 already.) He was ambassador to the United States from November 1, 1910 until May 29, 1914 (www.ambwashingtondc.esteri.it/Ambasciata_Washington/Menu/...) Another photo of him is in The Sunday Oregonian, February 13, 1910, SECTION FIVE, Image 55 (note that his name is misspelled as "Cusani-Confalioneri") with the caption: "Marquis Cusani-Confalioneri is the newly-appointed Italian Ambassador to the United States. He is present Minister to Switzerland, but he is expected at his new post in a few weeks . He succeeds Mayor des Blanches."
Thanks swanq and B-59. We'll add his full name to the catalog record.

"Arthur Zimmermann (October 5, 1864 – June 6, 1940) was State Secretary for Foreign Affairs of the German Empire from November 22, 1916, until his resignation on August 6, 1917." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Zimmermann
This picture is labeled Alf. Zimmerman.  Apparently, there was an Alfred or Albert Zimmerman in the German State Department in this era, though I think this photo is probably Arthur and mislabeled.

Oddly, all American newspapers of that time called the German Minister of Foreign Affairs "Alfred Zimmermann" (or "Alfred Zimmerman"), see e.g. - Morning Oregonian. (Portland, Or.) 1861-1937, March 02, 1917, Image 2 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1917-03-02/ed-1/se... (with this photo) - The sun., December 31, 1916, SECTION 4 PICTORIAL MAGAZINE, Image 33 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-12-31/ed-... (with photo) - New-York tribune., March 02, 1917, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-03-02/ed-... (with photo) - NYT November 26, 1916 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F07E5DA1F3FE233A... - East Oregonian : E.O., February 24, 1917, DAILY EVENING EDITION, Page PAGE SEVEN chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88086023/1917-02-24/ed-... (with photo) etc. I didn't find a newspaper that has "Arthur Zimmermann", but his name was certainly Arthur Zimmermann, see e.g. - wwws.phil.uni-passau.de/histhw/TutKrypto/tutorien/zimmerm... - www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/657233/Arthur-Zimmermann - www.firstworldwar.com/source/zimmermann_speech.htm - spartacus-educational.com/FWWzimmermann.htm - www.users.miamioh.edu/hadidotj/zimmermann/the-telegram.html ... In fact, I couldn't find a single German source that refers to him as "Alfred Zimmermann", and I couldn't find an explanation either why Arthur Zimmermann was "Alfred Zimmermann" in the American newspapers, though it is certainly the same person.

Thanks for the information B-59 & Art Siegel. It is Arthur Zimmermann. I'm not sure why his name is listed as Alfred. Maybe there was a mix-up in an early press release or article and everyone copied the mistake. I checked several German sources including the Bundesarchiv and they all list his name as Arthur.

The date on the sticker is 12/6/16. On the same day, the Bisbee daily review., December 06, 1916, Page SIX printed another photo of this type of tank with the caption "HERE IT IS! FIRST ACTUAL PHOTOGRAPH OF BRITISH "TANK" IN UNITED STATES" (but the same photo was in the East Oregonian, October 23, 1916, DAILY EVENING EDITION, Image 1 already).
a real turning point for the war

The length of the gun barrel and that there is only one per side identifies this as the "male" variant of the Mk I.  The Male Mk. I carried two QF 5 pounder Hotchkiss cannons (one per side).  The Female versions carried two machine guns in each side sponson.  

In practice the longer barrel of the Hotchkiss proved a detriment and later models used a shorter barreled cannon.

National Library of Scotland has another version of this photo

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/nlscotland/4687926165]

Thanks swanq, B-59, and Seuss for the information. We'll add it to our catalog record. I searched around and both the Imperial War Museum and the Library and Archives Canada identify this as one of Canadian Official photographer Lt. William Ivor Castle's photos taken in November of 1916. The Daily Mail paid £1000 to publish them on November 22, 1916. You can tell it's an early tank photo because it still has the "steering tail", the wheels attached to the rear. These were dropped early on because they were not liked by the tank drivers.

Probably Sir William MCMILLAN (1850 - 1926) adb.anu.edu.au/biography/mcmillan-sir-william-1105 www.parliament.nsw.gov.au/prod/parlment/members.nsf/0/d1f... According to records.ancestry.com/helen_rosamond_mcmillan_records.ashx... Rosamond (Helen Rosamond McMillan) was born in Randwick, Australia on 11 Oct 1895 to William McMillan and Helen Maria Gibson. From The Register (Adelaide) Friday 4 April 1924 trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/64203133 "Mr. H. H. Ainsworth, known on the stage as Frank Harvey, and at present leading man to Miss Emelie Polini at the Theatre Royal, Sydney, was on Thursday married to Miss Rosamond McMillan, daughter of Sir William McMillan. The bride, is a member of the Emelie Polini company." records.ancestry.com/marian_jocelyn_mcmillan_records.ashx... indicates that Jocelyn (Marian Jocelyn McMillan) was born in Randwick, Australia on 18 Sep 1894 to William McMillan and Helen Maria Gibson. Marian Jocelyn married Herman Petrus Gunnar and had 2 children. She passed away on 1949 in Riverside, Illinois, USA.

The evening world. (New York, N.Y.), 04 Dec. 1916, page 2, col. 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1916-12-04/ed-... reported the arrival of Sir William Mcmillan on the Ryndam, en route from Europe home to Australia.

A short biography of Lady Helen Maria McMillan (1863–1937) is in adb.anu.edu.au/biography/mcmillan-lady-helen-maria-11420. (According to records.ancestry.com/helen_maria_gibson_records.ashx?pid=..., she died in 1939)
